story:
who am I?

I am Alysha Farling, a visual artist from Montreal, Quebec. I am originally from Victoria BC, which is where I grew up and also received an Art Diploma from Camosun College. After graduating, my partner and I decided to move to Montreal where I just recently graduated (this past April) from Concordia University, majoring in Drawing and Painting.

what am I fundraising for?

My Indigogo campaign is to fund myself to be able to participate in my first artist residency in La Plata, Argentina. The residency is one month long (all of May). And I will be working on a sculptural project and at the end of my stay I will be exhibiting what I've created. 

In order to explain a little about the project I plan to do while at this residency, I want to share the main inspiration behind my sculptural work. 

When I was young I always wanted the ability to shrink down to the size of a mouse, bug, or something even smaller. I am an only child and grew up with a big garden and this is where I spent most of my time. I fantasized about living in between the little rocks, climbing up stalks of grass, and living in a damp world of moss. There was one shaded spot in particular, directly behind my house, where I would spend most of my time. When I sat myself down in front of these mossy rocks the whole world would grow around me and I would feel as though my hopes to shrink had come true. This garden was full of magic, the mossy rocks especially. 

As a kid, magic was easy to locate, but now I am finding it difficult. I am constantly trying to recreate the enchantment of that garden. When I talk about magic I am also including the dark and the strange – the tingly, the scary and the unexplainable.

I am also inspired by the fantastical animated worlds from cartoons, nature, the abject, and miniature things. I am also intrigued by the universal connection people have with each other through imagination. My desire is to draw out that imagination with my work.

For my project, I will be creating a giant character that will be wandering through the gallery. It will be free standing, larger than life-size and made up of many small details. It will be a character not of this world - both animal and human - with plants growing off of it.

While I am creating this character in the studio, I plan to be working outdoors as well, wandering the streets and parks, exploring and getting to know La Plata, Argentina. As I walk, I will be collecting objects - anything that calls out to me. This may be garbage, elements from nature, strange trinkets, things large or small. I will then take these objects and manipulate them, cut them up, rearrange them and paint over them to create elements of a small world on the character's back that will be floating behind it - traveling with it.

The final creation/creature/world will be fantastical, magical and strange but will reflect my experience in La Plata. As well it will  make reference to myself as traveler and transient, with the items I brought down with me, in my backpack, as my world.

phew! still with me?! okay lets keep going..


where exactly will the funds be going?

Heres a break down of where the money will be going:

$1,700 is for the specific residency program I applied for, which is a month long, with an exposition at the end. I get a live/work studio, and will have help documenting my work as well as promotion. 

$1,200 for my plane ticket.

I've given myself 15 dollars a day for food, which comes out to $450 and then $500 dollars will be for materials, such as chicken wire, hot glue, acrylic paint, paper, nails, fishing line ect..

what are the perks?

Some of the perks include, stickers, magnets, original drawings as well as an opportunity for us to collaborate on the project I will be working on!! I also want to draw your portrait! 

A BIG THANK YOU!

Thank you!!!  Your help doesn't need to only come financially - there are other ways - you can simply share my campaign with your friends and family and let them know they can do the same. 

Here is a link to the residency:

http://residenciacorazon.com.ar/site/index.php

My website is:

http://alyshafarlingart.tumblr.com

My e-mail is:

alyshafarling@gmail.com

I'm always open to feedback/questions/comments/critiques!

story:
Our Story

Hello from Rico and Takara, owners, artists and curators of the Rico Adair Gallery and Studios.


We opened our current gallery and studio space in March 2011 to benefit the neighborhoods of North Hollywood and Valley Village because we saw a need to add to the adjacent NoHo arts districts visual arts scene. We have provided many established and underrepresented artists the opportunity to show their works in our gallery.


This space is very welcomed by everyone in the neighborhood with great enthusiasm! We started building a great community art space and people are coming out to support us. We've hosted numerous gallery exhibits, art workshops and we sell unique gift items made by local artisans. We've also added an organic coffee bar to create community, inspiration, conversation and expression of thoughts.

We see a great need for this space as a place for artists, entrepreneurs and families to gather, share their work, pool their resources and to learn from one another. This space has a positive energy all it's own and everyone feels it from the moment they walk in. It is unique, non-traditional and open to all forms of expression. We see the gallery as a place where multidisciplinary arts can com together and flourish. Often, our art shows are interactive and show the artist's process.  Many of our exhibits have brought in 150 plus guest with visitors from the greater Los Angeles and San Fernando regions.


The Breakdown of funds

1) renovations

   4 mobile flats to divide the workshop rentals: finish gallery/ workshop floor: materials for defining workspace 

   rentals


2) create jobs/ hire 2 employees


3) marketing/advertising/ promotion


4) community enrichment

    art classes/workshops, collaborate with outside groups to create more events, open mic nights


5) coffee cart:

    expand the cart: add pastries, additional tables and chairs, 2nd fridge,


6) 3-4 months overhead

    while we grow!!


7) signage

    additional signage, exterior lighting and add greenery


The Impact


 We are building a bridge in the Valley Village art community to add and enrich the visual arts scene in NoHo and are a great asset to the community and local art scene.  We want to be a support for local talent and give them an outlet for expression and to have a place for the artists to speak to his/her community. It takes a village! We want ideas and free thinkers to come together. We need financial support to grow and continue on our mission.

 The community would greatly feel the loss of this space and the inspiration it has provided for so many who walk through our doors. Artists would lose a venue where they would have the opportunity to exhibit works that more traditional galleries often over look.  

 

Our neighbors and community support 

 Along with our neighbors, we hope to be a hub for the artists as a whole. By providing the necessary resources and outlets to support creativity, artistic commerce and expression of ideas. On our corner of Laurel Canyon Blvd, there are 5 complimentary businesses.  The first being Carter Sexton artists materials. They are the oldest artists supply store in Los Angeles and have a daily consistent flow of a diverse population of artist from beginning student to master artisans. We work closely with them to promote awareness of our growing community. Along with the materials they provide to artists, they also provide classes and workshops and hold monthly art openings in their gallery. On the corner of our block is Square One framer. Where the artist or collector can get high crafted custom frames for their works of art. Next to Square One is an Italian import furniture store. Where there are living rooms with fine Italian furniture there is art!! Directly next to us on the right is the Eclectic Theater Company.  We also coordinate with their show calendar to create greater community gatherings. 

In our space we have a retail art boutique, organic coffee bar, art gallery and we are preparing to provide artists with affordable monthly, daily and hourly work space. We educate through the visual arts, via classes, groups and workshops. The art boutique is a great retail shop for local artisans to sell their goods. The Art Gallery is another invaluable asset.




What We Need & What You Get

Our prayers, faith and hard work have gotten us this far. We are currently expanding and restructuring our business. Our goal is to create awareness and enrich the community. To do this, we need your financial support.

 

Our overall funding goal is $20,000 to cover our overhead as we build. This will ensure us to continue the renovations that will bring in enough money to keep the The Rico Adair gallery running permanently without fundraising.


If we are unable to reach our goal we will have to close our doors by December 31, 2011, IF NOT SOONER.


ANY amount you can send to us is greatly appreciated and will be put towards reaching our goal. 


We have a list of perks available for your support at varied levels, which you can see in the sidebar.


Thank you so much for your continued love, encouragement and support - it is deeply appreciated!


Please feel free to share this fundraising campaign with everyone you know! We have Facebook, YouTube and website links - feel free to add them within your own social media systems!

story:
Welcome to Jiji's Art &Scribble

We'll call it Jiji's App for short. My name is Tresa Bennett and I am the creator of Jiji's App and this is my very first time inventing a mobile app.  The app will feature art, music, kids games and you can scribble. What is Scribble? Scribble allows you to write messages with your finger or stylus when sending an instant message instead of texting. Just think when your child first learns to write their own name you can send it to the whole family. Also any art you or your child creates on the app can be posted to Facebook.

What excites me most about my app is that it will be a helpful tool for kids to communicate and express themselves especially kids who are not writing words yet. For kids who are writing or are just beginning to write it is a tool to practice and foster their writing skills while having fun. 

The Goal:

My mission with my first app project is aimed at keeping kids creative while saving moms and dads time and money .

The funds from my Indiegogo campaign will give me the money I need to have a developer build my app and put it in the App Store for iPhone users and make it available to android users.  These funds will get the app up and running with all the basic features loaded. 

The funds will help keep the costs low and that will help me to keep many free features on the app. I want everyone to have access to the app and bring as much joy as possible to kids and their families and friends.

There's More:

There's lots more I'd like to show here to give an idea of the direction the app will take as it grows past this first basic introduction.  Here is a fun video:

Here is a sneak-peek

Here are some of the mock-ups given to me by the developer. 1. Log In                      2. Choose which profile including artwork to visit. This is really helpful if you have more than one child.  3. Create art. 

 

Sign up for the launch: www.jijisapp.com

Spread the word. I thank you, the team at Jiji's app thanks you.

story:
PARA LEER EN ESPAÑOL, AQUÍ.

124+ pages 8.5 x 11IN, Red & Black Ink, printed on 125g matte paper, hand-sewn and expertly bound. We make books you will want to keep.

WHY THE NAME?

Taco de Ojo means “to get an eyeful” in Spanish, and is generally used to refer to checking someone out. We are reappropriating it to refer to images which provide food for thought: stories which spill off the page and continue to grow in the subconscious long after you have put our book down.

WHO WE ARE:

Latino Toons is a Latin American collective of comics, art and poetry, with collaborators stemming from the Rio Grande all the way down to Tierra del fuego. “Taco de Ojo: THE PINK BOOK”, gathers poets, illustrators & intellectuals in a joint exploration; combining elements from comics, design, illustration and conceptual art, we seek to push the boundaries of expression to a new frontier. We feel fortunate to count the very best illustrators from Latin America amongst our collaborators, and hope you will enjoy them too.  

WHO SHOULD BE INTERESTED?

We are convinced that the hybrid nature of our work makes it accessible to a wide audience, including those entirely new to the comics medium. All our publications are bilingual, and should be of interest to illustrators, geeks, and anyone who is curious about what happens when you combine Latin American industry professionals and young raw talent, unleashed in a compilation THE PINK BOOK. This combination of erotic comics, visual poetry & illustration delivers a powerful punch!

Taco de Ojo is a publication that intends to transcend national boundaries. With your help we can make this dream come true!

SOME OF OUR PRIZES:


KEEP IN TOUCH!

If you have any questions you can contact us in the following ways:

Email: latinotoons@gmail.com

Facebook:www.facebook.com/LatinotoonsComix

Twitter: https://twitter.com/LatinoToons

Website:www.latinotoonscomix.com/

story:
Paper, glorious paper!

Hereford trained artists show new artwork in London


In a nutshell we are 7 emerging artists with a booked gallery space in London to show works on Paper this October (15th to 22nd).  We would like to ask for your support with this and in return you will receive one of our perks and you will take us a step closer to our London exhibition!

We are in the process of updating this campaign (written on 11th Sept '14). 

Artists :

Alex Weaver
Catherine Wynne-Paton
Daisy Rickards
Ethan Seaton
Jack Clough
Kate Morgan-Clare
Rosie Daffern

In October 2014 we are showing new work at the R. K. Burt Gallery in Union Street, London, just 7 minutes walk from The Tate Modern and on the same road as The Jerwood Space (http://www.jerwoodspace.co.uk/).  This is the first time many of us have shown work in London so we are excited, nervous and ambitious for this project! 

The emphasis of PaperFields Exhibition is on the individual approach of each artist exploring the adaptability of paper within their work. 

We’re producing new work for the exhibition; we are curating and planning the logistics of getting ourselves and our work there, stewarding during the exhibition and have already designed the publicity material (thank you Daisy Richards), found sponsors for the Private View food and the printing of our invitations, flyers and posters (Kate Morgan-Clare did all this!) 

Tyrrells
Olivers Cider and Perry
Franks Luxury Biscuits
Ross-on-Wye Cider

& our printing costs has been covered by Impact Printing and Hereford College of Arts! (£400 in total for printing).

Framework Herefordshire is an organisation set up to support emerging artists with a link to the county and has provided support in the form of advice and office space with WiFi to use for meetings.

We need your help towards getting us there. 

We are asking for help with our travel, food and overnight expenses so we can put the final stages together in London and introduce our work to a wider audience.  6 of us have graduated in July from Hereford College of Arts and Kate is just beginning her 6th and final year of her part-time degree.  The cost of travel and staying in London is quite a challenge for us to meet and that is why we are asking for some support to bring our creativity to another region.

Our Fine Art course leader alerted us to the opportunity of holding an exhibition in London at R. K. Burt as she buys paper for the course from the company.  In return they offer their gallery free of charge to students and graduates on the understanding that all works promote the use of paper.

We are on IndieGogo to raise:

£310 Van, parking and congestion charge
£500 Travel for all by coach (£71 each) { by train £1035}
£690 B&B at Youth Hostel

£1500 TOTAL

As well as showing our work we want to promote the unique qualities of our college and county.  Kate Morgan-Clare says– “it’s really important to us that we represent HCA - it’s an amazing college which enables students to produce a wide range of exciting and high quality work.  We also want to promote Herefordshire to an urban audience and Jack came up with the exhibition title ‘Paper Fields’ to focus on our rural surroundings!”

Catherine  “It is thanks to a combination of the confidence built by supportive staff at college and our vision as artists that brings our work to show in London.”

Portfolio links to all artists websites and blogs:

Alex Weaver's blog
http://alexanderweaverart.tumblr.com/

Catherine Wynne-Paton's blog
https://www.a-n.co.uk/blogs/wood-for-the-trees /

and website:

http://www.wynnepaton.co.uk/

Kate Morgan-Clare's blog:
https://www.a-n.co.uk/blogs/hereford-college-of-arts-7

Rosie Daffern's blog:
http://thelifeofhedgepig.blogspot.co.uk/

Ethan has recently been artist in residence at The Rodd, Presteigne run by the Sidney Nolan Trust.

Catherine is the recipient of the Meadow Arts 2014 Graduate Prize and is currently The Print Shed artist in residence.

Kate Morgan-Clare’s work was selected for The Ludlow Open in 2012 and 2013 and The Herefordshire Open 2013.


Watch our progress on here and on
 https://www.facebook.com/PaperFieldsatBurts

course leader alerted us to the opportunity of holding an exhibition in London
at R. K. Burt as she buys paper for the course from the company.  In return they offer their gallery free of
charge to students and graduates on the understanding that all works promote
the use of paper.
We are on IndieGogo to raise:
£310 Van,
parking and congestion charge
£500 Travel for all by coach (£71 each) { by train £1035}
£690 B&B at Youth Hostel£1500 TOTAL


As well as showing our work we want to promote the unique
qualities of our college and county.  Kate Morgan-Clare says– “it’s really important to us that
we represent HCA - it’s an amazing college which enables students to produce a
wide range of exciting and high quality work. 
We also want to promote Herefordshire to an urban audience and Jack came
up with the exhibition title ‘Paper Fields’ to focus on our rural
surroundings!”
Catherine  “It is thanks to a combination of the confidence built by
supportive staff at college and our vision as artists that brings our work to
show in London.” 
Portfolio links to all artists websites and blogs:Alex Weaver's bloghttp://alexanderweaverart.tumblr.com/
Catherine Wynne-Paton's bloghttps://www.a-n.co.uk/blogs/wood-for-the-trees
/
and website:
 http://www.wynnepaton.co.uk/ Kate Morgan-Clare's blog:https://www.a-n.co.uk/blogs/hereford-college-of-arts-7Rosie Daffern's blog:http://thelifeofhedgepig.blogspot.co.uk/
Ethan has recently been
artist in residence at The Rodd, Presteigne run by the Sidney Nolan Trust.
Catherine is the
recipient of the Meadow Arts 2014 Graduate Prize and is currently The Print
Shed artist in residence.

Kate Morgan-Clare’s
work was selected for The Ludlow Open in 2012 and 2013 and The Herefordshire
Open 2013.
Watch our progress on here and on  https://www.facebook.com/PaperFieldsatBurts

story:
"Cuando me preguntan que busco, tengo que hablar primero de las historias de mi abuelo, de cómo mi tatarabuela Micaela perdió la cabeza y de los pájaros azulejos. Al contar estas cosas, aún con lo difícil que es comprender a otros, quizá pueda explicar porque me gusta contar historias y mirar al cielo."


Español
English

Hola, mi nombre es Santiago, soy estudiante de último semestre de Artes Plásticas en la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, sede Medellín, y este es mi proyecto: "De los abrazos, los adioses y los azulejos”. Un libro ilustrado que cuente la historia de Daniel, del cariño que éste tiene por su abuelo y de lo difícil que es decir adiós.

Hello, my name is Santiago. I’m a student in the last semester of fine arts at Universidad Nacional de Colombia in Medellín and this is my project: “De los abrazos, los adioses y los azulejos” (of hugs, goodbyes and bluebirds). An illustrated book which tells the story of Daniel, his love for his grandfather and how difficult it is to say goodbye.

 

Aceptar la muerte, darse la oportunidad de creer y el cariño que se puede tener por otros, son algunos de los tópicos que trato en este cuento, que está basado en un mito de una antigua tribu indígena de mi región sobre un pájaro azul que podía llevar plegarias a Dios para así hacerlas realidad.  

A partir de este mito he producido mi obra, con la cual busco explorar a través de la experimentación plástica y la intervención de los imaginarios y la memoria colectiva, proponiendo nuevas metáforas y producción de símbolos, por medio de la apropiación y resignificación de imágenes preexisten es en ésta.
Accepting death, giving oneself the chance to believe and the love that you can have for others are some of the topics what I talk in this short story, which is based on an indigenous tribe myth from my region about a blue bird who could take prayers to God and make them true.

Parting from this myth, I created my work, with which I seek to explore through artistic experimentation and the intervention of the imaginary and collective memory, proposing new metaphors and symbols, through the appropriation and redefinition of existing images on it.

Como propuesta plástica se encuentra la producción del libro ilustrado, piezas bidimensionales y objetos escultóricos, que den cuenta del mito de los azulejos; Permitiéndome la exploración de medios plásticos como la ilustración, el pop-up, el dibujo y los procesos pictóricos y escultóricos. Con la que optaré por el título de maestro en artes plásticas, y que presentaré en una exposición el viernes 29 de mayo.

He escuchado decir muchas veces que el arte te salva y a mí me ha permitido ver cosas maravillosas en el mundo y en los otros, por eso, poder realizar este proyecto me permitirá compartir esa visión del mundo con otras personas.
As plastic proposal will be the illustrated book, some two-dimensional pieces and sculptural objects, which will realize the myth of the bluebirds; allowing me the exploration of plastic media such as illustration, pop -up, drawing and pictorial and sculptural processes. With which I will opt for the title of Master in plastic arts. My work will be on an exhibition on Friday, May 29.

I've heardmany times that art saves you and for me art has let me see marvelous things in the world and in others. That’s why carrying out this project will let me share this vision of the world with other people.

Espero te guste mi proyecto y quieras ayudarme a hacerlo realidad. Cada aporte suma muchísimo y pone este sueño un paso más cerca de hacerse tangible.

Te invito a conocer más de mi trabajo a través de mis redes sociales, donde encontrarás fotos, dibujos y algunos fragmentos de mis escritos. 
I hope you like my project and want to help make it happen. Each contribution adds a lot and makes this dream a step closer to reality.


I invite you to take a look at more of my work through my social networks, where you will find pictures, drawings and some fragments of my stories.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, I am a graduate student at SVA Interaction Design and an artist. 

I have been obsessed of 2D/3D art, using canvas and human figures and playing with light and shadow, for a past few years. I have a great passion for making this type of art depicting human relationships. I would love to share with whoever out there who has similar interest and appreciate the art. 


What I Need & What You Get

I need minimum of $1,000 which mostly will be used for purchasing basic materials. 

If you order and purchase this HAND-MADE canvas art in exchange you will receive the canvas art made out of human figures, threads, metal sheets, etc. 

Every piece will be different and unique. The piece will have different atmosphere depending on the where user puts it. (Hanging it on the wall or displaying down)

 My prototype on the picture is only a basic mock-up to give you the slight sense of what I will make. 


Risks & Challenges

Since my project is HAND-MADE, you might be seeing the light traces of glues. I will try my best to make is invisible. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with somebody, through SNS or word of mouth, who might be interested with this type of art.

story:
Help spread the word against Ivory poaching through Photography art.

The only one of it's kind - so far

My name is Karue Wachira, a nature and wildlife photographer living in Kenya. I have dived in and out of photography and gone and epressed myself through other forms of art before I found myself back home - Photography.

I was Lucky enough to travel the country, Kenya, a lot last year (2012) and got very close to wildlife which I have been passionate about since I was a child. The travelling had its good times and not so good ones. The good times for me were when I get so close to wildlife and there was almost a communication between us - like they were reminding me who I really was and who I really am. It's an amazing feeling of serenity. The not so good times were every time I heard an animal has been killed by poachers. To think the future generations will miss this.

I have wanted to do this project for sometime, to be a part of the creating awareness about the poaching through my art but for lack of funds I opted to wait till I could fund it. So in my small way I have been raising awareness throug twitter :). A friend introduced me to Indiegogo.com and I was excited with the thought that the wait might be over.

This campaign through Photography art will help spread the awareness and touch a few more people to play a part against this evil. I would like this Stop Ivory Trade Photography Exhibtion in Nairobi to be the first part of the project. After this project is successful here in Nairobi, I would like to take part two of this project to 5 other major cities in the world. London, New York, Ottawa and especially Beijing and Hong Kong being in the East and the biggest market for illegal IVORY.

The exhibition will show from 12th August 2013 WORLD ELEPHANT DAY - 20th August 2013 at the KICC, Nairobi, Kenya.

 

How we will do this together.

With your genorous help you will help me spread the word in a different way. Beautifully I hope. The funds raised here will be used in:

Production which will include

1. An upgrade for some of my equipment - for that I will be forever gratefull :).  The equipment will help improve the quality of the art and help send the message out better

2. Transport around the wild while shooting

3. Accommodation and meals

The exhibition and the awareness

1. Printing the 24pcs on Canvas 24x36inches

2. Framing

3. Promotional material (Posters and fliers)

I would have loved to send some of the pieces to backers of the project but sending anything from here will need another fund raiser. For that reason I would like to sell these pieces and DONATE all the funds raised to A Rhino sanctuary in Kenya that is doing a very good job of saving RHINOS. With each framed 24x36inches canvas print being sold at USD 1000. I feel this way we will have achieved:

1. Help raise awareness against POACHING and IVORY trade

2. Help me gain more experience, exposure as a photographer and from here I'll walk away with upgraded equipment which I will be forever grateful.

3. With sale of the art, help the day to day conservation of Elephants, Rhinos and other animals in the wild with proceeds raised.

Note :: I have partnered with George's Legacy Fund run by a very passionate conservationist - Raabia Hawa where the proceeds from the sale of the art will go to, to help continue with the awesome job she is doing in conservation.

In the case that the funds raised are not fully sufficient I want to believe the project will still start and keep looking for funds to finish it. This should be a campaign that should not stop till the poaching stops or at least reduces significantly.

I have had an exhibition before to highlight the beauty of a forest within Nairobi through the life in the forest. 25% of the funds raised from the Exhibition was donated back to the forest for it's maintenance. This was through butterflies and was featured in a national newspaper - The Standard- both in print and their digital version

http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/?articleID=2000060332&pageNo=1

There are Other Ways You Can Help

You may not be in a position to contribute to this cause in monetary form but please let's all be a part of this campaign against POACHING and IVORY TRADE.

Any other type of help Material or otherwise will be appreciate

Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools please!

 

During this project I will be posting it's development on my facebook Photography page :  https://www.facebook.com/KarueWachiraPhotography and my twitter status whenever possible: https://twitter.com/Qarue

story:
Who is the Still Moon Arts Society?

            We were formed 5 years ago with a group of passionate community members who believe in promoting environmental awareness and community engagement through the arts.  Our mission statement is “inspiring vibrant and connected communities by creating artistic experiences and nurturing a passion for nature.”

 

            What is the Moon Festival? What’s its importance?

Still Moon founded the Moon Festival to celebrate the full moon and harvest abundance, and  honour diverse cultural traditions. The festival is instrumental as it not only brings awareness to the environment through the arts, but it does this while fostering intercultural relations and a sense of community. Today (September 29th, 2012) marks the 10th year of the festival, which on average brings together 3,000-5,000 community members each year.

 

This festival is so important to our community as it brings attention to our local Renfrew Ravine. This ravine was used as a garbage dump and wasn’t appreciated by our community, but since the Moon Festival has begun we have witnessed a decrease in garbage and an increase in community interest in protecting the ravine.

 

Personally, I am a current university student and have been a part of the festival since grade 8. I have been able to grow with the festival and I find myself falling in love with its beauty year after year. Carmen Rosen, the artistic director, puts her heart and soul into running this festival every year and inspires thousands of people to appreciate their environments at the same time. It’s truly an incredible event and I hope to see it continue to flourish in the coming years.

 

            What is our goal?

            We have had trouble with grants recently because of the large amounts of applications that they receive. A large part of our costs involve providing honourariums to our many staff and artists who work tirelessly to create a beautiful festival. We believe in paying artists the amount they deserve. In other organizations, artists’ wages are often the first to be cut under budget constraints. So to make sure the Moon Festival continues to run, we turn to our community members and Internet users from around the world to support our cause. We understand that there are many campaigns on this site, but we hope you can see what makes our festival unique and important. Our goal is currently $3,000, which will cover a portion of the costs and will help us greatly in our festival’s sustainability.

 

            Perks?

            You don’t think that we would just gleefully accept your donations without providing a perk, did you? We have some very unique perks to provide, including 2012 Moon Festival T-shirts, all-expenses paid lantern workshops, tours of our unique Renfrew Ravine, and more! Of course, you will also receive eternal appreciation from all of the organizers behind the Moon Festival.

 

            Will you help us?

            We can’t say enough how much we have appreciated the support we’ve received for the Moon Festival thus far. We hope to see future growth, and hope that you’ll stick around for the ride. In the meantime, we would appreciate your donations to make the festival possible. Share this page, invite your friends to the festival, and walk the Renfrew Ravine! Take care and thanks for your consideration.

story:
ABOUT THE ARTIST:

Fine artist Larry Poncho Brown was invited to share his talents abroad with Artists 2 Africa, participating as a teacher on this tour representing his discipline of painting. He is one of several artists throughout the U.S. invited to teach other creative mediums including: Carren Clarke-Mcadoo (VA), Shurvon Haynes (WA), Jolyn E. Gardner (WA), Karen Y. Buster (MD), Tommy Roberts (MD), and Ethan Holland (PA), to name a few. A noteworthy group of American artists exchanging creative education with African artists!

ABOUT A2A:

ARTISTS 2 AFRICA was birthed from decades of artists discussing the prospect of organizing a group journey to Africa tailored specifically for artists and focused on art education. On October 19-30, 2013 we will embark on our second official journey to Ghana West Africa!

The artists will journey into the art villages on the outskirts of Ghana. Various artisans including painters, sculptors, and weavers will be gathered in their workshops to create and collaborate. We will fellowship with the artists and students, visit their workshops to share technique, and explore the creative process, while exchanging our creative ideas with the artisans in the region. An exhibition will be organized featuring the works of each artist. Our focus is to educate and connect through ART.

HOW WILL YOUR FUNDS BE UTILIZED?

With your support we hope you will assist us with this unified effort. As you can see on the right...the artist has graciously donated his art for perks for your contributions. The campaign is to assist us with acquiring art materials for other artists to use on our visit as we fellowship by creating art. We will be visiting 4 locations where ceramic, wood carving, fabric making and other artforms are taught and produced. We will introduce various art projects and will instruct several groups of artisans and other participants. Funds will assist with art supplies and materials, and small tools. We also plan to document this experience with photography and video as a future educational medium. We hope you will take advantage of this unique opportunity to assist with this project....thank you. Share.Teach.Create!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! 

My name is Jenna Pearl Morgera, I am currently a Junior at Laguna College of Art & Design. I am a Painting and Sculpture major. This past summer I had my first exhibition, which included my first body of work (25 paintings) from Netherlands and France. Now I am ready to begin my next body of work; digging deeper into myself and following my dream to share the love and peace of enlightened masters with the world.

This campaign will send me to a six day retreat in Sedona, Arizona over New Years, with an enlightened master. There I will be able to look deep within myself and heal, bringing more clarity to my life and to my artwork. In reverience to this beautiful and divine expereince I will create my next body of work (mostly oil paintings/ charcoal drawings). The infinite healing and love that I will experience at this retreat, held by my beloved Guru, will be infused into this next body of work. This is beginning of what my life and mission as an artist is: to share my spiritual journey into the heart of God with humanity; the journey into my own heart and my walk with an enlightened master. My vision is to share this love of God and self to the world through my work.

By donating to this campaign you will be the angel’s who will make this dream and vision possible! By donating you will have had a hand in helping heal and give love to all the people who will come in contact with this body of work.

Please check out my art work in the Gallery Tab! Includes painting and sculptures!

 

What We Need & What You Get

I will need $3700 in total. The retreat cost is $2700 (paying for my stay at the Enchantment Resort, where the retreat will be held, and food), and another $1000 for materials; including canvases, paper, oil paint, and charcoal. 

When you donate $100 or more you will receive an original drawing and, or oil painting from this next body of work. Donate at all and receive a personalized thank you card and invitation to my next exhibition in 2013!

If I do not reach this goal, the funds will go to supplies and tuition to help me get through my schooling! Those who have donated at all will still receive a personalized thank you card with a sketch inside and those who have donated $500 or more will still be receiving an original plein air oil painting of the beautiful nature surrounding southern California! 

 

The Impact

Your contribution to this campaign will be helping the love and peace of my experience at this retreat, reach the world through my art!

Last summer I raised $5600 to travel to the Netherlands and France with my school to create my first body of work! Each person who donated received a certain size painting; when I returned I had my first solo exhibition that was very successful selling more paintings than ordered! 

This is a chance of a lifetime to help a young artist dig deeper into her healing and artistic calling to help share love through art!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not donate at this time, no worries! Please let others know about my campaign and vision to share love and healing through art with the world!

Share with Facebook, Twitter, and Tumblr friends!

Use the Indiegogo share tools, for easy sharing!

Thank you for your support!

Namaste <3

story:
Our Story

We wish to emulate the famous Bauhaus which schooled and harbored some of the greatest of the 20th century artists.  studio spaces for freelance artists of any medium. a gymnasium and forum for exchanging ideas germane to truth, love and beauty. a cafeteria and a theater.

It will be called the NOHO Bauhaus



The Impact

NOHO (North Hollywood) is already a hotbed of writers, actors, painters, sculptors etc..  What we need is unity.  but not a formal union with all the bureaucratic encumbrances;  just a place to work with others; a place for accomplished artists to transmit their knowledge in their field.

What We Need & What You Get

Like the model, the Bauhaus can become self sufficient.  All we need is creative people working together to create what will in time be as legendary as the Bauhaus.  a lump sum to lease the buildings for five years is the aim.  we can accrue equipment as we go along.  these buildings in North Hollywood have been vacant for as long as i have been here, which is four years.  every single dollar will help, but a generous donation will yield for the giver all kinds of lovely benefits and appreciations.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are an artist living in the area you can not only contribute what you can in dollars but get together with us to launch fund raising campaigns on the ground.  a collaborative auction/masquerade party to meet and greet and spread some excitement. we need all the help we can get.


Credo

Our grand aim is the ecstasy of creation. We understand art idealistically, a priori, as the purest activity.  The joy of creation, like love, transcends time. 


Our great purpose is to work in a free atmosphere
1.      A lack of money will not prevent participation.  Bring what you can to each class (at least as much as the cost of a bottle of wine or the going rate to see a movie.)
2.      If money is no problem, then a lump sum will be donated to the general ‘kitty’.
3.      There will be no grades, no competition, and no government intervention or collusion. Compliance with ordinances and insurance requirements of any business will be strict; to avoid legal hassels.
4.      There will be frequent gallery shows, screenings, plays, recitals, poetry nights and lectures presented by teachers to ensure revenue for equipment, salaries, rent and utilities.
5.      Trade will be encouraged.  For example, one might donate an etching press worth many thousands of dollars in lieu of cash for tuition.

Training to become a true artist consists of emotion, brain and body working harmoniously. This takes practice.
Our practice will be the study of the crafts of all the arts and the transmission of real knowledge of the practical laws and techniques; both traditional and current.  Let those who know tell those who do not know. But we are all equal. Of course a subliminal hierarchy will be common and even a teenager may have an authority lacking in the elders. We can all learn from each other through exchanges and healthy argument.

story:
Hey, thanks for stopping by! We are so excited to bring this project to you. There's two of us in this; Lissy Marlin, artist and traveler, and me, Barbara Perez, editor and consultant. 

Last year, Lissy went to 4 different countries between May and June. Now, we've put together an AMAZING collection of art inspired by these places. Along with this, there's also stories and commentary about her trip. Here's where YOU come in! You could get yourself a copy of this awesome book through this campaign.

The book is going to be approximately 150 pages of delightful, original art! It's split in sections covering the countries Lissy visited. From the canals of The Netherlands, the traditions in Germany, seeing art in France, and walking through Spain.

We will be printing 500 copies of the book and creating a pack of 5 postcards (80 packs available) from some of the art from the book. 

UPDATE (7/10/2014): ALL PERKS $25+ WILL NOW INCLUDE AN 8 PIECE STICKER SET! BECAUSE EVERYONE LOVES STICKERS AND WE LOVE YOU FOR HELPING US!

UPDATE (8/1/2014): We will be printing another batch of postcards and after allocating some of the books have added 25 more slots to each of the 'Explorer' and 'Frequent Flyer' Perks.


Keep on reading, let's talk about the details!

               

As mentioned, the book will be approximately 150 pages long and here's the specs for it:

8x8 inches, perfect binding, and glossy cardstock cover.

Sections include:

  • Intro 
  • Germany
  • Netherlands 
  • France 
  • Spain 

The postcards will be printed on cardstock and have a glossy finish. They will feature art from the book and will be 5x7 inches. We will be printing 400 of these, which will make for a total of 80 5-packs.


Our priority is to bring YOU a quality product, in order to do that, we're going to have to meet our goal which will help us cover the following costs:

Printing Costs - We'll be working closely with the press to guarantee that the final product will not disappoint. 

Shipping - Once the book is done, we want to make sure it makes it to you in a timely and successful matter. 

Materials - Once the book is done, we want to make sure it makes it to you in a timely and successful matter. We're going to need envelopes and additional elements to ensure a safe delivery. A lot of the art in the book will be digital, HOWEVER, Lissy is making 10 traditional-styled pieces that will be featured in the book and making these will also require some additional resources. More details on these later on! 

Other Expenses - Even though we are totally awesome, Lissy and I learned the hard way that money doesn't grow on trees. We tried. This project will take time and effort that we are more than glad to invest. Unfortunately, we are working long distance and these funds will help us greatly to cover costs of travel to each other once the more demanding parts of the project come around. Any leftover funds after that will help us bring other projects to light in the future!

We are not letting you go empty handed though! As we build up to meet our goal, these perks will make sure that you are satisfied with your investment:











Don't forget: ALL PERKS INCLUDE DOMESTIC SHIPPING WITHIN THE USA!


    Lissy and I have known each other for a while, but this is our first adventure publishing something together. This would be the first of several projects we've got in mind. Seeing this campaign reach its goal would only add to our motivation to continue bringing our work to the world!

    Here's some of our background:                      

                               

    Lissy attended The University of The Arts in Philadelphia, PA. She's a freelance illustrator and has interned at Applehead Factory. If you are not familiar with her work, you can check her website at www.lissymarlin.com

                              

                             

    Barbara is an MFA candidate at Manhattanville College in Purchase, NY. She's a fiction writer and she's edited for Inkwell Magazine and The Manhattanville Review. You can check her stuff here: www.mustachebabs.com


    We don't want this just to be special for us though, we want to include you! That's why we want this project to bring you little nuggets of our hard work through the perks we already mentioned! We seriously thank you for just reading this, 



    Like everything in life, there's always the possibility of risks. If any were to arise, we'll make sure to notify you immediately! As far as we can envision, these are the immediate things that could detour from a timely fulfillment of the project: 

    • Delays, whether during printing or shipping.
    • Life, we'll do our best to keep it from interfering but some things are out of our control.


    And what if you can't help? That's fine! If you could share this, that would be great! Maybe you have a friend that's crazy about traveling? Send them our link! We'd love it if you could spread the word around the world!


    Now you are done reading, but maybe we didn't cover something you'd like more details about? Not a problem! Please feel free to reach us and we will address any inquiries.

Life, we'll do our best to keep it from interfering but some things are out of our control.

story:
What is the Clio Art Fair?

The Clio Art Fair is a Manhattan-based artist showcase which has "... the primary goal is to create a space for direct dialogue between artists and collectors, artists and curators without the presence of any long-term mediator". The Clio Art Fair showcases the work of independent artists for a fee. That fee includes:

- Presence of curators and dealers throughout the Fair
- Online presence in the web-catalog for the show at ClioArtFair.com

- 10 VIP Pass for the VIP Preview on October 11th, 2018.

-  5 VIP Pass for the Art Lovers Networking Breakfast on October 12th

-  5 VIP Pass for the Art Lovers Networking Breakfast on October 13th

- Social Media Exposure

- Art Handling

- Lighting

- Internet wi-fi

Past artists include Vito Acconci (Whitney Biennial 1977, 1981, 1991; Venice Biennial 1976, 1978, 2003), Nina Berman (Whitney Biennial 2010), and Zana Briski (Academy Award for Documentary Winner, 2004). 

Who the hell is Kat Haggerty?

I am a Social Media Marketing consultant by day, and a fine artist by night (and weekends). I started painting in 2015 after becoming chronically and dangerously ill. I had studied fine arts and photography in college and planned on pursuing photography as a career. While sick I lost my will and ability to photograph, but not to create. Due to a tight budget, I opted to use Crayola crayons and a Conair travel hairdryer as a painting medium. I instantly fell in love with the process and began experimenting with techniques. Painting carried me through my illness and now carries me through my recovery as I piece my life back together. The Clio Art Fair is not just an opportunity for me to push my career forward as an artist but also to push myself forward in my recovery. 

What I Need

This campaign is to raise funds to cover the Clio Art Fair showing fee, transportation/parking fees, and for any canvas hanging supplies, I may require. 

What You Get

What's in it for you? Perks!

$5 - Get exclusive updates about my show prep and a shout out on social media.

$15 - A signed 5x7 postcard print of one of my paintings.

$25 -  Get a signed 8x10 print of one of my paintings (different painting from the postcard). 

$50 - A personalized thank you on my website and a second signed 8x10 print (different featured painting). If we hit the reach goal of $1,750 you will also receive a mini painting (5x7 in). 

$100 -  1 VIP Pass to join me at the Clio Art Fair opening ceremony & preview on October 11th (limited to 5). 

$500 - 1 VIP pass to join me at the Clio Art Fair Networking Brunch on October 13th or 14th (limited to 4). 

$1000+ - 2 FREE commissioned paintings up to 24x24 in (limited to 2). 

My goal for this campaign is to raise $1,500 with a reach goal of $1,750 an a second reach goal of $2,000. If we reach $1,750, everyone that contributed $50 or more will get a mini painting (5x7). If we reach $2,000, everyone who donated will get a secret code for at least 15% off any painting in my Etsy shop. The more you donate, the higher the percentage. 

Thank you for your generosity! 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that some people won't be able to donate but would still like to help. Please share this campaign with everyone you know, and tell everyone you've ever met! Indiegogo has share options, so don't be afraid to abuse them.

Follow me on Social Media and help me spread the word.


Instagram

Facebook

NEW! deviantArt

Etsy

NEW! YouTube

story:
Bernard & Cross is a passionate artisan startup located in Ottawa, Canada. We are committed to designing and producing elegant and intuitive greeting cards, many of which are geared towards men but are giftable to anyone.  

This business started because we noticed that many of the greeting cards in the market weren't well tailored to men, with some being downright silly. This is where we saw a niche to create an elegant collection of cards that resonate with our target audience. 

Use of mostly dark grey lines and a small range of colours assures the cards have a simple and elegant feel.  (Please see the Gallery above for examples of our work).

Our designs start with a pencil drawing, then are carefully transcribed into an electronic format and printed at a local print shop on 100% recycled card stock paper.  All cards will be shipped to you in rigid mailers.

* Website viewing format shown. Actual card will be folded in a traditional greeting card format with the message on the inside. All cards are 5 by 7 inches with a matte finish.

 Coming soon: www.bernardandcross.com

 

What we're doing with your money:

Even simple products such as greeting cards have development and startup costs. Your kind contribution will help Bernard & Cross produce an amazing series of greeting cards.  It will support the graphic design and printing process and facilitate the distribution of these cards to small artisan stores, as well as the creation of an online store.

We are hoping that your funding will help us startup our business, but we also want to make a positive impact. Bernard&Cross will donate 25 percent of all donations from this Indiegogo campaign to the Movember charity which supports prostate cancer and male mental health initiatives. 

 

Example of a "Love and Affection" card:

* Website viewing format shown. Actual card will be folded in a traditional greeting card format with the message on the inside. All cards are 5 by 7 inches with a matte finish.

 

Here are our initial costs:

  • Designing and perfecting each card ($250 software license cost, $100-$200 trial printing and trial printer cost)

  • First batch of cards ($300 - $500)

  • Envelopes and packaging costs ($40) for first batch

  • Website hosting by Shopify.com ($30 per month) 

 

Example of a "Congratulations" card:

 Examples of "Thank You" cards:

* Website viewing format shown. Actual cards will be folded in a traditional greeting card format with the message on the inside. All cards are 5 by 7 inches with a matte finish.

For more examples of our cards please see the Gallery

This business started because we noticed that many of the greeting cards in the market weren't well tailored to men, with some being downright silly. This is where we saw a niche to create an elegant collection of cards that resonate with our target audience. 
Use of mostly dark grey lines and a small range of colours assures the cards have a simple and elegant feel.  (Please see the Gallery above for examples of our work).
Our designs start with a pencil drawing, then are carefully transcribed into an electronic format and printed at a local print shop on 100% recycled card stock paper.  All cards will be shipped to you in rigid mailers.
* Website viewing format shown. Actual card will be folded in a traditional greeting card format with the message on the inside. All cards are 5 by 7 inches with a matte finish.
 Coming soon: www.bernardandcross.com
 
What we're doing with your money:
Even simple products such as greeting cards have development and startup costs. Your kind contribution will help Bernard & Cross produce an amazing series of greeting cards.  It will support the graphic design and printing process and facilitate the distribution of these cards to small artisan stores, as well as the creation of an online store.
We are hoping that your funding will help us startup our business, but we also want to make a positive impact. Bernard&Cross will donate 25 percent of all donations from this Indiegogo campaign to the Movember charity which supports prostate cancer and male mental health initiatives. 
 
Example of a "Love and Affection" card:
* Website viewing format shown. Actual card will be folded in a traditional greeting card format with the message on the inside. All cards are 5 by 7 inches with a matte finish.
 
Here are our initial costs:


Designing and perfecting each card ($250 software license cost, $100-$200 trial printing and trial printer cost)


First batch of cards ($300 - $500)


Envelopes and packaging costs ($40) for first batch


Website hosting by Shopify.com ($30 per month) 


 
Example of a "Congratulations" card:
 Examples of "Thank You" cards:

* Website viewing format shown. Actual cards will be folded in a traditional greeting card format with the message on the inside. All cards are 5 by 7 inches with a matte finish.
For more examples of our cards please see the Gallery

story:
(I took the video down, since there are only several days left - check out my art and donate to help me make more art and stuff)

Visit my Deviantart to see the most recent Pocket Art!!!

Howdy, I'm Josie Nemo and I'm a transsexual. I'm also a aspiring artist-entrepreneur. I'm here to ask you for a leg up to help me pay for some upcoming doctor visits and prescriptions. As you may know, most medical coverage doesn't cover this and right now I can't afford basic care, much less that. That said, this is the most important thing in my life more important than anything that has come before. And so for me to succeed in life, it's a necessity.

But I don't just want to rely on the kindness of friends and strangers - I'm hoping to get enough donations so that I can also make my business self-sustaining. For it to flourish, I need to be able to buy more supplies.

Some of those supplies will be a sewing machine and other sewing supplies, tubing and electronics for LED hulahoops and wands, ink pens, and gardening supplies. I intend to sell LED wands and hoop, upcycled garments and accessories, art, and eventually plant starts for local gardeners.

Regardless of whether I reach my goal, you will receive the listed perks. Your generosity will help me fulfill myself as a woman as well as become financially self-sustaining. Thank you for taking the time to consider this.

Please check out the perks pictured and listed below, as well as my Facebook, it has more examples of more, as does my DeviantArt account:

LED Wands unlit and lit. Stayed tuned for YouTube videos of me dancing with them. Newer wands will be slightly more impressive!

My original upcycled bag, still serving me well after years of use. Yours will be freshly sewn :) Making a cameo in this is a prototype of an LED cork-light.

Health Stuff:

Sadly, it looks like I'm not going to raise even $100, which still isn't enough pay for my upcoming medical bill. Trying to raise this money was pretty much the only reason I've fought myself to simply stay alive and continue trying. At this point, I've been trying to raise money to transition for nearly a year with little success. Due to circumstances beyond my control, I haven't been able to get a job and the money I had raised earlier in the year went to a therapist in hopes they could write a recommendation for medical treatment (they could not).

While it might seem like I'm a chronically depressed individual who needs a psychologist and antidepressants, I've tried both for years. Psychotherapy hasn't helped me at all, despite my sincere efforts to jump through their hoops. Antidepressants have been worse - when they work, they induce a pseudomania that I'm not equipped to function under and my ability to make rational decisions is severely compromised. In short, what will make me a functional individual is HRT. While I realize antidepressants may be a more common treatment for depression, remember that I'm treating a chemical imbalance in my body, which is the underlying problem in my existence, instead of a non-existent chemical imbalance in my brain.

I realize a year may not seem like a long time and in some senses it isn't. However, add to that the past decade-and-a-half of struggling with my gender identity to begin to understand how frustrated I am living like this. To finally have come to understand myself and take action is the culmination of a lifetime of pain. Pain I want to end, preferably by becoming the person I truly am.

This fairly-unsuccessful campaign was my last hope, a desperate attempt to finally ask other people for help. Despite my best efforts, I've found myself more desperate and disheartened, due to the continued lack of success and increasing nearness of the endocrinologist appointment that's scheduled four days after this campaign ends.

And while this campaign page isn't fancy, I had hoped people would take action to help me. After continuing to trt my best to make this the best page that I can, I've had two donors (Babs & Sarah, thank you again) in about two weeks of running this campaign. Apparently I was generally wrong that people would be willing to take action. For the next two weeks, I'll keep trying  even though I'm losing hope. There are two weeks left to help me. After that point, I don't know if I'll have any hope left.

story:
We think the world would be a better place with more Leopold Bloom and finely printed letterpress books in it. Are you with us!?!

That’s the bottom line for our project – an unlikely trans-Atlantic collaboration between Jamie Murphy, a Dublin-based designer and letterpress printer, and Steve Cole, a James Joyce fanatic from Baltimore. We are out to bring the unique wit, warmth, and quirkiness of the everyman hero from James Joyce’s Ulysses to light for the first time in a glorious letterpress printed limited edition artist’s book.

We want to have this new book completed in time for this year’s celebration of Ulysses on the 16th of June – a day known around the world as BLOOMSDAY.

What? You haven’t read Ulysses? Well, who can blame you. It is a monster of a book. At over 700 pages and written in a dozen different styles (some utterly bizarre) it is not an easy read. But there’s a reason why it is widely considered the greatest novel in the English language. Ulysses gets inside and behind and underneath a human life like no other book. And that whirlwind of styles opens your eyes to a whole new way of seeing and reading.

With this project we boil down the essence of Leopold Bloom into a collection of his thoughts and sayings. We want this book to help the uninitiated experience Bloom’s all-too-human world view. For Joyce junkies the book will be a fresh look at Bloom through his quips & quirks. And to make this experience really special, we’re bringing out our “Quotations from Chairman Bloom” in a large-format hand-printed volume that will be a wonder to behold (and hold).

WE JUST WANT TO PLEASE MOLLY BLOOM

Truth be told, the idea for this Joycean undertaking is not ours. We stole it. Not from a living being, mind you. We lifted it from no greater an authority on Leopold Bloom than his own wife, the erotic and unfaithful Molly Bloom. Mrs. Bloom, in her bed at the end of that eventful day in 1904, muses admiringly about her spouse: “I declare somebody ought to put him in the budget if I only could remember the one half of the things and write a book out of it the works of Master Poldy yes.”

“The Works of Master Poldy” is our second collaboration together involving Ulysses, letterpress printing and Dublin. We were strangers just a year ago. In early 2012 Steve was revving up for a second year of feeding his Ulysses addiction, which in 2011 burst onto the global scene with a 24-hour Twitter rendition of the whole novel. Jamie was wrapping up his M.A. degree at Dublin’s National College of Art & Design and bringing out his letterpress book “Albert, Ernest & the Titanic.”

To mark the end of copyright on Joyce’s published works in Europe last year, Steve launched the LiberateUlysses project to encourage multimedia expressions based on the novel for Bloomsday 2012. He was eager to indulge another passion – letterpress printing – and thought it would be cool to work with a Dublin printer on a Bloomsday project. Of course, he didn’t know any.

But through the miracle of Twitter, Steve found Jamie @fjorddesign and together with @maryjplunkett they brought out a series of large colorful broadsides of Ulysses quotes, printed at the fantastic @DistillersPress in Dublin. Our “Ulysses Strands” posters were a great success and are now sold out.

A BOOK PRINTED BY HAND IN DUBLIN

Our project will be the first publication from Jamie’s new book arts & letterpress printing venture in Dublin – The Salvage Press – which he established just this year. The Salvage Press is devoted to preserving, promoting and pursuing excellence in design, typography and letterpress printing. Jamie has a huge interest in finely printed artists’ books, having recently completed an award-winning tome based on the printers who travelled aboard the Titanic in 1912.

Handprinting a beautiful book like this takes a LOT of time, and we will be going all-out to get it done ahead of Bloomsday. That’s less than three months away, so it’s going to be a MAD dash! Don’t hate us if we miss that date by a few days, but be assured we are doing everything possible to make sure “Master Poldy” arrives in time for his big day.

So pitch in and help us realize Molly Bloom’s century-old publishing vision! We believe that the world will be a little better off with this letterpress book in it. We hope you do too.

WHAT WE NEED TO CREATE “MASTER POLDY”

This new book will be printed at the amazing Distillers Press, National College of Art and Design, in Dublin, where Jamie is about to undertake a design residency for the coming year. Our Indiegogo campaign funds the design, typesetting (both monotype casting and hand-set metal and wooden type), letterpress printing and hand binding of “Master Poldy” using traditional letterpress methods. Jamie is handling all of this and is already at work on the design of what we know will be a beautiful book. Steve has already finished harvesting a rich crop of Bloomisms from Ulysses.

The funds we raise go toward the labor and materials needed to produce an edition of 120 copies by early June 2013. If we raise more than our goal, we plan to start work on bringing “Master Poldy” out in other formats that will let us put the book into the hands of more people.

“Master Poldy” will be a 40-page book, case bound within a protective slipcase, measuring about 10 x 15 inches. (We’ll also have a deluxe edition with a more elaborate binding and some hidden extras.) It will be letterpress printed onto Zerkell mould made paper, keeping the beautiful deckled edge where possible. We’ll be using a mix of traditional monotype methods and handset antique wooden type in an experimental typographic design. By creating the book at Distillers Press, we have over 500 cases of type to choose from.

WHAT YOU GET FOR CONTRIBUTING

We’ve come up with lots of fun perks that will please Joyce addicts and letterpress enthusiasts alike.

We are designing original stickers using lots of letterpress-printed type in three new designs and a set of Bloom-inspired postcards letterpress printed from wooden and metal type – all great ways to share your love for the craft of letterpress printing and the writings of James Joyce. You can also receive a large typographic poster (letterpress printed, of course) inspired straight from the mind of Leopold Bloom. These will be fantastic colorful pieces printed by hand on mould-made paper in a small edition.

You can also receive the standard and deluxe editions of “The Works of Master Poldy.” The standard edition will be a beautiful book – a very special keepsake for Joyce enthusiasts and the avid bibliophiles. The deluxe edition will have a more elaborate binding/housing with some special extras included.

Our top-level contributors will receive a personal tour of Distillers Press and a celebratory meal with us in Dublin on Bloomsday weekend 2013.

If you can’t contribute financially but want to help us bring “Master Poldy” to life, we’d really appreciate your help in spreading the word about our project. We’re all over social media @LiberateUlysses and @TheSalvagePress and online at:

The Salvage Press

The Liberate Ulysses Project

Bloomsday 2012 ‘Ulysses Strands’ Broadsides

The Distillers Press

story:
[English version follows]

S'inscrivant dans une longue tradition des centres d'artistes autogérés au Québec et au Canada, VIVA! souhaite poursuivre sa mission en permettant au public de participer gratuitement à toutes les activités du festival Cette campagne s'adresse à ceux et celles qui aiment l'art actuel et qui souhaitent faire un don en soutien aux artistes de la performance et de l'art action et aux organismes qui les soutiennent.

GARDONS VIVA! LIBRE

VIVA! est une manifestation internationale d'art performance située à Montréal qui présente des artistes de partout au monde. Ayant obtenu moins de financement que dans le passé, VIVA! fait l'impossible pour offrir des conditions de travail décentes et un accueil généreux aux artistes invités.

Plutôt que de recourir à une billetterie – un développement qui irait à l’encontre du désir de garder VIVA! accessible à tous – VIVA! demande à ceux et celles qui le peuvent, de faire un don soit au moyen de cette plateforme Indiegogo, ou encore, en déposant des sous directement dans la tirelire pingouin installée bien en vue, à l’entrée du Bain St-Michel. Les fonds recueillis durant cette campagne serviront à maintenir minimalement les activités de l'organisme durant l'année off, entre deux festivals.

Certes, VIVA! est reconnaissant à l’endroit du Conseil des arts de Montréal et du Conseil des arts et des lettres du Québec pour leur soutien au fonctionnement et au projet, fonds qui permettent aux centres d’artistes articule, DARE-DARE, Centre CLARK, La Centrale Galerie Powerhouse, OBORO, Praxis Art Actuel, le Centre des arts actuels Skol et Verticale de collaborer à la 4e édition de cet événement biennal.

Avec sa cuisine fonctionnelle aménagée dans l’ancien vestiaire du Bain St-Michel, VIVA! offre des repas équilibrés à prix modique aux membres du public qui veulent côtoyer cette unique communauté d’artistes. Ceux et celles qui ont assisté aux éditions antérieures de VIVA! se rappelleront les délicieux repas préparés par l’artiste SP38, qui pour cette édition 2013, a produit le logo avec sa police bien singulière. Pour cette édition, les repas seront préparés par l’artiste Torontois Basil ALZeri dont le service culminera avec une performance le dernier soir du festival.

Nous vous invitons à venir assister à une ou à toutes les soirées; et, pour ceux et celles qui ne pourront être présents, vous pourrez suivre toutes les actions en lisant les chroniques de nos blogueurs Jacob Wren et Marc-Antoine K. Phaneuf. La programmation détaillée est disponible sur le site de VIVA!


HELP KEEP VIVA! FREE

Free admission is a long-standing tradition in the not-for-profit artist-run network in Québec and Canada. This campaign is intended for lovers of art who are looking for altruistic opportunities to support living artists and their organisation.

VIVA! is a Montréal-based international event that draws artists from every continent. With significantly less funding than past years, VIVA! still manages to offer decent work conditions and generous hospitality to our guest artists. Instead of charging everyone at the door, VIVA! is asking those who can to make donations using either the Indiegogo platform or by dropping some coin into the VIVA! penguin bank, located at the entrance of the Bain St-Michel. Funds collected with this campaign will mostly go toward keeping the event alive in the off-year, between festivals.

Of course, VIVA! is grateful to the Montréal and Québec arts councils for their operating and project funding, which allows artist-run centres articule, DARE-DARE, Centre CLARK, La Centrale Galerie Powerhouse, OBORO, Praxis Art Actuel, le Centre des arts actuels Skol and Verticale – centre d’artistes to collaborate on the 4th edition of this biennial event.

With a fully operational kitchen set up in the Bain Saint Michel, VIVA! offers daily meals at a low cost to members of the public who wish to mingle with this special crop of artists. Everyone that has attended past editions of VIVA! will remember the tasty meals provided by Berlin-based artist-cook SP 38, who, for this edition, was invited to design the 2013 logo using his signature font. This year’s suppers will be prepared by Toronto artist Basil AlZeri and will culminate with a closing performance.

We encourage you to attend at least one evening of performances during the event and, if you absolutely can’t, why not follow the daily actions on our blog featuring authors Jacob Wren and Marc-Antoine K. Phaneuf?For more info and programming, visit the VIVA! website.



L'équipe / The VIVA! team

Centres partenaires/Participating artist-run centres 2013: articule, DARE-DARE, Centre CLARK, La Centrale Galerie Powerhouse, OBORO, Praxis Art Actuel, le Centre des arts actuels Skol and Verticale – centre d’artistes; Conseil d'administration/Board of Directors: Anne Bertrand, Catherine Bodmer, Rachel Echenberg, Virginie Jourdain, Thierry Marceau, Christian Bujold, Manon Tourigny, Nicole Burisch and Julie Tremble; Programmation/Programming: Comités de programmation et commissaires des centres partenaires/Programming committees and curators of the participating artist-run centres; Coordination/Coordinating team 2013: Michelle Lacombe, Alexis Bellavance, Florence S. Larose; Documentation/Photographer 2013: Guy L’Heureux; Graphisme/Graphic designer 2013: Olya Zarapina (en/in collaboration avec/with SP 38); Développement web/Web programer 2013: Captivator (Farid Rener)

.

Les fonds recueillis durant cette campagne serviront à maintenir minimalement les activités de l'organisme durant l'année off, entre deux festivals.



Certes, VIVA! est reconnaissant à l’endroit du Conseil des arts de Montréal et du Conseil des arts et des lettres du Québec pour leur soutien au fonctionnement et au projet, fonds qui permettent aux centres d’artistes articule, DARE-DARE, Centre CLARK, La Centrale Galerie Powerhouse, OBORO, Praxis Art Actuel, le Centre des arts actuels Skol et Verticale de collaborer à la 4e édition de cet événement biennal. 




Avec sa cuisine fonctionnelle aménagée dans l’ancien vestiaire du Bain St-Michel, VIVA! offre des repas équilibrés à prix modique aux membres du public qui veulent côtoyer cette unique communauté d’artistes. Ceux et celles qui ont assisté aux éditions antérieures de VIVA! se rappelleront les délicieux repas préparés par l’artiste SP38, qui pour cette édition 2013, a produit le logo avec sa police bien singulière. Pour cette édition, les repas seront préparés par l’artiste Torontois Basil ALZeri dont le service culminera avec une performance le dernier soir du festival. 




Nous vous invitons à venir assister à une ou à toutes les soirées; et, pour ceux et celles qui ne pourront être présents, vous pourrez suivre toutes les actions en lisant les chroniques de nos blogueurs Jacob Wren et Marc-Antoine K. Phaneuf. La programmation détaillée est disponible sur le site de VIVA!




HELP KEEP VIVA! FREE



Free admission is a long-standing tradition in the not-for-profit artist-run network in Québec and Canada. This campaign is intended for lovers of art who are looking for altruistic opportunities to support living artists and their organisation.

VIVA! is a Montréal-based international event that draws artists from every continent. With significantly less funding than past years, VIVA! still manages to offer decent work conditions and generous hospitality to our guest artists. Instead of charging everyone at the door, VIVA! is asking those who can to make donations using either the Indiegogo platform or by dropping some coin into the VIVA! penguin bank, located at the entrance of the Bain St-Michel. Funds collected with this campaign will mostly go toward keeping the event alive in the off-year, between festivals.  

Of course, VIVA! is grateful to the Montréal and Québec arts councils for their operating and project funding, which allows artist-run centres articule, DARE-DARE, Centre CLARK, La Centrale Galerie Powerhouse, OBORO, Praxis Art Actuel, le Centre des arts actuels Skol and Verticale – centre d’artistes to collaborate on the 4th edition of this biennial event. 

With a fully operational kitchen set up in the Bain Saint Michel, VIVA! offers daily meals at a low cost to members of the public who wish to mingle with this special crop of artists. Everyone that has attended past editions of VIVA! will remember the tasty meals provided by Berlin-based artist-cook SP 38, who, for this edition, was invited to design the 2013 logo using his signature font. This year’s suppers will be prepared by Toronto artist Basil AlZeri and will culminate with a closing performance.

We encourage you to attend at least one evening of performances during the event and, if you absolutely can’t, why not follow the daily actions on our blog featuring authors Jacob Wren and Marc-Antoine K. Phaneuf?For more info and programming, visit the VIVA! website. 



L'équipe / The VIVA! team
Centres partenaires/Participating artist-run centres 2013:
articule, DARE-DARE, Centre CLARK, La Centrale Galerie Powerhouse, OBORO, Praxis Art Actuel, le Centre des arts actuels Skol and Verticale – centre d’artistes;

Conseil d'administration/Board of Directors: 
Anne Bertrand, Catherine Bodmer, Rachel Echenberg, Virginie Jourdain, Thierry Marceau, Christian Bujold, Manon Tourigny, Nicole Burisch and Julie Tremble;

Programmation/Programming:
Comités de programmation et commissaires des centres partenaires/Programming committees and curators of the participating artist-run centres;

Coordination/Coordinating team 2013:
Michelle Lacombe, Alexis Bellavance, Florence S. Larose;

Documentation/Photographer 2013:
Guy L’Heureux;

Graphisme/Graphic designer 2013:
Olya Zarapina (en/in collaboration avec/with SP 38);

Développement web/Web programer 2013:
Captivator (Farid Rener).

story:
Our Story

My name is Dino Mangano, and I am a high school teacher, as well as a freelance photographer!  One of my passions, in addition to photography, is wine, specifically Michigan wine.  Most of America knows about the West Coast wineries, but very few know about the amazing wines made here on the "North Coast".  My dream is to create a Michigan Wineries Photo Book that is as vibrant, unique, and appealing as the wineries and vineyards it will contain.


The Impact

Not only will this book be a wonderful collectors item, but it will help to open the eyes of American wine lovers to the special wines created here in Michigan, a State that is in dire need of positive economic growth.


What We Need & What You Get

This plan will not be overly expensive, but any endeavor like this is just out of my tight budget at this time.  While all of the photography and design work is finished, the last great hurdle is printing costs.  I had a few publishers willing to print and distribute, but wanted to change the artistic format to a 'tourist guidebook'. This is, and always has been, an artistic project, and needs to stay that way.  So I will be self-publishing.  In order to generate enough hardcover books to fill the shelves of all the stores and wineries who've already agreed to carry it, as well as create marketing materials, i'll need at least the Goal Amount of $3000.



Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word!  This project can help not only a blossoming photographer, but also lend a helping hand to a wonderful area of a wonderful State.
