                                                 Thanks, son!





Short Summary About Us

We are a
small creative family-based company residing in the most beautiful         country in
Europe!
 MICHELANGELO
d.o.o. CROATIA, EU     
 



The company
was founded by a married love couple 







Vjekoslav and Maja Flegar.

           


   Vjekoslav -  Facebook                     Maja -  Facebook   
                                                                                                                                                                 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------   
Expert
company for manufacturing wall and ceiling interior or exterior decorative
elements, EPS plastering, facade plastering, decorative ornaments and indirect
lighting profiles.
We produce unique wall decorative panels - 3D WALL ART Panels (we are the only
manufacturer in the world.) All of the panels are hand-made and have artistic
value. Recreations of elements such as stone, raw terrain, and similar
structures, artificial decorative stone, artificial rocks - Faux Rock, or
artificial recreations of wood - decorative "wooden" shapes, pillars,
boards.
3D Titles, ads, and articles used in scenography.
Production of mold shapes, and modeling of complicated architectural elements.

www.michelangelo-art.net

MICHELANGELO - Facebook

Our project - 3D Wall Art 



Because our
company primaraly revolves around producing wall decorations and decorating the
interior, we always strived to create special and unique products. That's why
we fabricated something completely new based on decoring the interior. The
Michelangelo 3D Wall Art Panels are an alternative to the industrialy produced
3D panels which are produced using a single blueprint and in reality don't
have any artistic value. We produce panels by request exactly by measure. An
example would be if a wall we wanted to place the panel on were to be 4m in width and in height 2,5m. We would
produce 4 panels with the height of 2,5m and the width of 1 m which can be
placed on the wall and without any cutouts and waste. 

When they
are placed, they form a unit.

                              1.                                                          2.

   
                                                                             3.      
               .                                                                                                                                             


                              4. Panels
are placed and painted !    


                                              It is unique and looks fabulous  
                                COLORADO 3D  Wall  Art -  on living romm wall
      
                               For each project , we issue the signature of the artist.     
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------     The goal of our campaign:
The goal of our campaign is to raise $20,000 dollars to achieve 
serial production of 3D Wall Art Panels. We need AutoCAD software to 
make designing our new products and shapes easier. Aswell as that, we 
require a special CNC foam cutting machine. As of now, we pushed two 
basic lines of panels; COLORADO - inspired by the Grand Canyon, and 
ADRIA - inspired by the Adriatic sea.We have an abundance of new 
ideas for textures, for example the texture of ice, inspired by the blue
 polar ice, aswell as the texture of tree bark and many others! By 
purchasing the software and the machine, we would upgrade and increase 
the capacity of our production and push new lines of 3D panels on the 
market. Along with using the CNC machines, in every product we add 
lots of love and the finishing touch of a hand that makes each product 
unique and gives it an artistic value, in the spirit of our company name
 Michelangelo. 
Until now, people show enthusiasm towards our project, and we recieved excellent recommendations.
We
 have $20,000 of our own money and we need to raise another $20,000 to 
acomplish the goal of our project !  
AutoCADSoftware....................$10 000CNC foamcutter machine.......$30 000                                   




We unusually love what we do !  

Therefore, we ask you to help  us to start production of 
Michelangelo 3D Wall Art panels, and to be able to compete with large 
companies !  No one puts in as much soul in their work as we do!
We can ship the products anywhere around the globe. Just sends us a picture of the wall it would be placed on and the size/dimensions. We design it by measure and we ship it, and you yourself or a local worker can easily set it up. Every shipment comes with a signature of the artist.

Even if you cannot help us financially, we would be thankful of any 
spread word, to family, friends, colleagues, designers and would ask to 
introduce them to our campaign. We prepared nifty perks, so take a look 
at the pictures below.
 
            BIG THANK YOU!!!                                             From Maja, Vjekoslav, Marin & Ena !
                                                        
                                                  Our home & workplace !

         
           Marin                     Maja                          Ena                              Vjekoslav

                                       Creative mess in our workplace !            
                                                                            3D Panels ADRIA in production.      

 
                               1 piece 3D Panel COLORADO - 105cm x 230cm     

        
            COLORADO 3D Panels & Unique external lights of our design.
               Our little girl started following Mom and Dad's steps !
           

            
     





     Looks awesome in discotheques, night bars, taverns, pubs...





                                             -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------      Now, we
produce two basic lines of

story:
Short Summary

We are Erin Canady (instagram: @erin.canady) and Michael Riesch (instagram: @cardboardcouch). We are artists, husband and wife, and the creators of SLOUCH tattoo & art gallery. Erin is a fine artist and teaches at local colleges. Michael is a tattoo artist and illustrator. We have been making art our whole lives, and want to create a space that breaks down the barriers within our art worlds.

SLOUCH will be a place for all art to coexist. It will uplift and pay artists within the community. It will house an art retail space, a gallery with rotating exhibitions, and three private tattoo studios. The retail space will consist of locally sourced creative goods such as prints and functional ceramics. The gallery space will feature original works of art from artists near and far, giving priority to marginalized and under-represented artists. The private tattoo studios will be safe, welcoming, and unintimidating. Combining tattooing within the same space as contemporary exhibitions will help break down stereotypes the general public has when entering both a traditional gallery space and a traditional tattoo shop.

Contributing to our campaign will allow this unique creative space to come to life. Not only will it propel our business, but it will propel the representation of artists within our community and Western North Carolina at large. It will also help carve a niche for an important conversation about art that doesn't fully exist yet in the area.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We already have some funding. However, we need more! We need your help raising $10,000, which will go toward the cost of getting our space up and running. This includes:

  • New walls, drywall, lighting, paint.
  • Initial stock on tattoo supplies (gloves, medical coverings, ink caps, plastic wrap, etc.)
  • Getting the retail space ready, which includes purchasing local art and buying furniture, display shelves, etc.
  • Initial payroll for our first employee.
  • Initial bills for the first month in the space, including rent, utilities, insurance, etc.

 

The Impact

Our main goals are to:

  • Make contemporary art accessible to the general public in both affordability and understanding.
  • Bridge the gap between appreciation of high-brow and low-brow art by housing them in the same space.
  • Uplift and pay artists in our community with priority to marginalized and under-represented artists.
  • Create a tattoo environment that feels safe, calming, and inclusive.
  • Build a space that champions all avenues of creativity while dissolving barriers surrounding traditional galleries and tattoo studios.

 

Risks & Challenges

SLOUCH will be located in a 1200 sq foot stand alone building in Weaverville, North Carolina. Most of our community and existing clientele is in Asheville, which is about 15 minutes south of Weaverville. This distance is both a challenge to our business and a potential benefit. We chose this location intentionally for the following reasons:

  1. We hope it will help us span our reach to not only Asheville, but the surrounding cities that are less saturated with art but equally as deserving of it.
  2. A lot of Ashevillians enjoy traveling to Weaverville because it is an escape from the bustle of tourism. Our space feels like a getaway. There is a beautiful view of the mountains from the front, and an outdoor gathering/event space. It is 3 minutes off of the on-ramp to I-26, yet in a setting that feels secluded and special.
  3. Since we have an established tattoo clientele already, foot traffic is not important to us. Instead, we want to hold bi-monthly events to encourage new people to come out and bolster community involvement.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money, you can still help by:

  • Spreading the word! Share our goal and campaign on social media, with your family & friends.
  • Donating labor! Do you want to help us paint walls? Move furniture? Hang art? Let us know!
  • Donating supplies! Let us know if you have something you think a gallery or retail space could use.
  • Donate items that we can use as perks for our campaign backers (we're thinking art, prints, ceramics, experiences, etc).

story:
Brooklyn International Performance Art Festival (BIPAF)

July 4-28, 2013

BIPAF is a mass performance. Performance artists, curators, critics, gallery directors, cultural organizers, and many others are working together to perform a festival, framing the organization and the festival itself as a work of constructive institutional critique.

Over 200 individuals are participating in this festival.

Performance art is social research, relational practice, and political assembly. Performance artists are not creating luxury objects, performance artists work with human Being, create alternative social situations, and operating across class, race, nationality, gender identity and sexual orientation, envisioning and then actualizing cultural gatherings and actions.


Right now, BIPAF participants are donating time, materials, and pooling all of their resources to make this festival happen. We see BIPAF as an epic culmination of our community's ability to pull together in absolute destitution, and to combine our practices for maximum impact. Performance art has long existed on the margins of arts industries, largely unsupported and critically neglected. As such, performance art-making, or organizing for the discipline, is not a paying job.

 

For International participants, BIPAF's formal no-budget structure means paying for plane tickets out-of-pocket, even for local artists this means paying for materials, transportation, and donating time. For the organizers, this means 40+ unpaid hours per week, all while we each work day jobs and/or produce our own practices. None of the spaces are rented, all are donated. The incredible generosity of artists, spaces, and curators is already demonstrably historic. We all believe so strongly in performance art as a social tool that we are compelled to work, no matter if we must do so outside of capitalist structures for reward and punishment.

To an extent, this no-budget approach is intentional, we exist via mutualism, collaboration, and simple sharing. However, we need to make a website and catalog at the very least, to make it possible for audiences to even attend the festival.

$26,000 is a bare minumum amount for making the BIPAF website, festival catalog, purchase adspace, and provide supplemental funds to the spaces for light bulbs, toilet paper, and other functional neccesities for the public. Beyond this amount, we will split funding evenly between all participants.

 

Grace Exhibition Space (Jill McDermid and Erik Hokanson), Panoply Performance Laboratory (Esther Neff, Brian McCorkle, Valerie Kuehne), The Woods Co-Operative (Lindsey Drury), Gowanus Ballroom, Matthew Silver, CAVE Art Space (Raul Zbengheci), No Collective, Glasshouse Projects (Lital Dotan and Eyal Perry), IV Soldiers (Ivy Castellanos), Kathinka Walters, 109 Gallery (Ryan Krause), Fitness Center for Arts and Tactics (Miles Pflanz and Laura Bluer), Teena Lange, PERFORMEANDO/Nexus Sur Nexus (Hector Canonge), Goodbye Blue Monday, JACK (Alec Duffy), and the No Wave Performance Task Force, are just a few of the current spaces, individuals/curators, and organizing entities. If you have a space, are an organizer/curator, or have  other cultural resources/skills/needs, get involved! We are always open to ideas, criticism, and collaboration.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Some people just can’t contribute money, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:To volunteer time, materials, resources, housing (couch? floor?) for International artists, to get involved as a performer, visit the wiki atwww.bipaf.net/bipafwiki and e-mail bipafbipaf@gmail.com

 

If you would like to make a major gift, you can recieve a tax-deduction by donating through one of our fiscal sponsors. E-mail bipafbipaf@gmail.com

 

All contributors will be acknowledged in the festival catalogue.

story:
Who Am I and What's This Project All About?

My name is Sarah Cargill and I am the curator for “But Tell Me What It Feels Like: The Erotic Practice of Liberation”, a multidisciplinary performing arts festival set to take place on May 4th, 5th and 6th at SOMArts Cultural Center in San Francisco. It is with tremendous gratitude and excitement that I share SOMArts’s inaugural performing arts festival and my curatorial debut with you!

The festival grounds itself in the theoretical framework articulated by Black lesbian feminist poet and activist Audre Lorde in her essay, “Uses of the Erotic: The Erotic As Power”, where she describes the erotic as a rigorous, liberatory practice where it is, “not a question of what we do alone, [but] a question of how acutely, how fully we can feel in the doing.” While the erotic can and does allude to sexualities, sensuality and touch, it is, within this context, a point of reference through which artists and audiences alike are invited to locate a well of deep-seated bodily wisdom through the sharing of performances, visual art, and workshops. While this festival certainly is about boldly envisioning the future we want for ourselves and our communities, it is also about dropping into the urgency of this very moment. What does liberation feel like in our bodies? How do we generate that feeling right now?

In my own experience as a social justice-oriented classical musician and through witnessing the physical, mental, and emotional toll that this work has on my colleagues, I have noticed the individual and collective pain that musicians and other artists in various fields carry in their day-to-day attempts at creating meaningful, satisfying, and liberatory art.  Through this festival, I aim to provide a creative space for participating artists and audiences to find liberation in their work by exploring the erotic in its many forms.

Check out the festival details here.

 

About SOMArts Cultural Center

SOMArts leverages the power of art as a tool for social change through multi-disciplinary events and exhibitions. Equipping artists with the space, mentorship and support they need to shift perspectives and innovate solutions, SOMArts fosters access to arts and culture for collective liberation and self-determination.

 

What We Need & The Impact of Your Support

In combination with the amount awarded to this project from SOMArts Cultural Center, I am looking to raise an additional $1,500 to cover the cost of paying our artists for creating new works and generously sharing their resources directly with the community.

All monies raised will go directly to the 15 participating artists, most of whom are folks of color and identify along the spectrum of queer, trans and femme-of-center identities. In addition to recognizing artists for their labor and creative generosity, it is my goal to support artists who embody socio-economically marginalized identities. As an artist and curator, I believe that we must call on the creativity, vision and skill of artists to build futures that we wish to be a part of, and I am devoted to amplifying the voices of those whose work and lives are deemed most precarious yet urgently necessary within our current social and political climate. Their voices have been and continue to be a crucial part of our community and movement-building, and your donation would go towards supporting and sustaining their work.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not in a financial position to donate, there are other ways that you can support this fundraising effort and this festival. You can share this campaign on social media and your other networks and, of course, join us on May 4-6th at SOMArts Cultural Center. We hope to see you there!

 

Text for Video

Hi everyone! My name is Sarah Cargill, and I have the distinct honor of being SOMArts's debut Curatorial Resident for the Performing Arts. I'm so excited to be sharing with you the culminating project of this residency. It's a three-day festival on May 4th, 5th and 6th called "But Tell Me What It Feels Like: The Erotic Practice of Liberation", which takes the text of Audre Lorde's work "The Uses of the Erotic: The Erotic as Power" as a theoretical framework to talk about the many different uses and functionalities of the erotic. We plan to explore those things through performances, installations and workshops.

Audre Lorde describes the erotic as this rigorous, liberatory practice, where it's not really a question of what we do alone, but how fully, how acutely we can feel in that doing. And so, me as a curator, and our artists - our festival artists - we are all contending with the question of how do we use our craft as a way to tap into the erotic and tap into the functionality of the erotic as our source of power.

Now, I'm willing to bet that there's probably some part of you that clicked on this link and is watching this video because you believe in the importance of artists in our communities, in rallying our communities together and propelling our movements forward, and envisioning and embodying a future that we all wish to be a part of. 

As a curator, it's my goal to make sure that I'm amplifying the voices of artists who straddle the intersecting identities of being queer, trans, PoC, Black, femme-of-center, folks with disabilities - it's my goal to actually amplify those voices in a way that is sustainable and also honors their creative labor, and the work that it takes to actualize these visions that we're all having.

Now, to be clear and transparent, these artists are getting paid for their time, generosity, energy and their creative labor. And, the reality is that many of these artists are living and working in conditions where their work and their labor is often undervalued and underfunded. And so it's my goal, through this campaign, to try to mitigate some of the impacts of these inequities that we have to exist in.

And this is where you all come in.

I'm looking to raise an addition $1,500 dollars to cover the cost of these artists creating new work and sharing their resources directly with you, for free fam! So come through, y'all! Donate, share this campaign with your friends, your homies, your loved ones, and I will see you at SOMArts Cultural Center in May.

story:
*Version française: voir "Updates"
*Deutsche Version: siehe "Updates"

As Spray Peace our main goal for the year 2016 is to organise a camp for youngsters from around the Balkans called PEACE WE CAN - a project combining art and peace dissemination through collective and individual art creation as well as workshops.

Who are we?

We are Spray Peace and we believe that art is a very powerful means of expression! We think it is a great way to start a dialogue and advocate the benefits of multiculturalism and tolerance. We want to erase the negative connotation that graffiti has acquired through its origins and use its strength to advocate peace. It is an art form with a great potential and we want to use it to promote our values of respect and tolerance.

As an NGO we organise a range of activities combining peace and art. We regularly organise cling film painting actions that are open to the wide public, ranging from young children to seniors. This allows people to discover a new form of art and help us spread the word of peace at the same time. Apart from that, we are working on organising youth art-camps in specific places, where peace is still at threat. Those youth camps aim at using graffiti as a common ground for peace-building and respect.

All of that leads to the PEACE WE CAN project.

Our Spray Peace Team after the first cling film action in Luxembourg.

What is PEACE WE CAN all about?

PEACE WE CAN will be a youth camp in the summer 2016. It will consist of a range of activities, both artistic and thematic. The setting for this first edition of PEACE WE CAN will be the Bosnian capital Sarajevo. Youngsters from 5 different countries all around the Balkans will gather for 10 days around their common passion, art in general and spray can art in particular. There will be guest artists involved in delivering workshops to the participants, in order to help them improve their artistic skills ranging from sketching to actually spraying. Both individual and collective murals will be created. Alongside of that, a number of contextual activities around tolerance, peace and multiculturalism will be carried out by our experienced board members. The emphasis is on the multicultural exchange that is to happen throughout this experience.

In terms of accommodation, we will be hosted by the foundation “Land of friendship and peace” in Rakovica, Sarajevo. It was founded shortly after the 1992-1995 war to organise activities for orphans of the region and it generally shares the values and intentions of Spray Peace. In return we will help embellishing the foundation with murals. We are also aiming at creating a big collective mural in the centre of Sarajevo.

A view of the “Land of friendship and peace” in Rakovica, Sarajevo.

Why is PEACE WE CAN important?

Spray Peace believes it is about time to forget about our differences and underline what we have in common and what brings us together. Even if 2015 marks 20 years of peace in Bosnia, the aftermath of the rivalries in this region is still noticeable. It is therefore crucial that now people get aware of the inestimable value of peace and how vital it is to preserve it. 

To this day, there are hate crimes being perpetrated throughout Bosnia. Those crimes are often committed by young people and are discriminating against ethnicities and religion. This creates a tense atmosphere amongst the communities which could be avoided. It is exactly why we want to target those young people with this project. PEACE WE CAN will give them an invaluable opportunity to meet people from other cultures in a different and positive context.

This camp will have several scopes of impact. First of all, it will act as non-formal education for the participants, who will improve their social and team-work skills. They will learn the benefits of diversity and spread the word of the importance of peace. Moreover, it will have a positive impact on the local community; materially by embellishing places and buildings that to this day bear traces of the fights and psychologically by conveying a strong message of tolerance and respect.


Why is it worth your support and what will you contribute to?

All in all, we are asking you to help us make this very special camp come true as we believe that big changes start with small steps. Every little contribution will bring us closer to achieving our main goal and hence making this world a better place.


Your donations will contribute towards funding the following:

- accommodation and food for the participants

- artistic materials

- transport to the different working sites

You can help us make a change!

Also if you wish to make a donation please find our bank details below:

SPRAY PEACE A.S.B.L.
1221 LUXEMBOURG

IBAN: LU63 1111 7037 8954 0000

BIC/SWIFT code : CCPLLULL

A huge thank you from the Spray Peace team !!

story:
TYPOS 2015 - CONVIVIO

8 chef, 21 creativi visionari, 5 container...
Siamo un gruppo di giovani professionisti – grafici, giornalisti, fotografi... – che hanno a cuore la diffusione di una cultura creativa.
Nel 2013 abbiamo dato vita all'Associazione Culturale Typos, in memoria del nostro amico e collega grafico triestino Marco Stulle. Lui, come noi, avrebbe voluto che la grafica, e le arti affini, diventassero sempre più "affare di tutti". Ecco perché da quell'anno abbiamo iniziato a lavorare, tutti gratuitamente, per organizzare ogni anno un'esposizione che rendesse la grafica più "commestibile". Nel 2013 la prima, poi nel 2014 la seconda, con un grande seguito.

Quest'anno abbiamo deciso di fare un passo ancora più grande. 

Così abbiamo chiesto ad otto chef di altissimo livello di regalarci una delle loro ricette. A quel punto abbiamo dato il via a 21 creativi che hanno creduto nel nostro folle progetto e hanno deciso di condividere con noi quest’avventura: undici grafici/illustratori, quattro fotografi, due videomaker, un sound designer, una pittrice, una scrittrice e una disegnatrice di gioielli sono stati abbinati agli chef e hanno restituito la loro personale visione della ricetta assegnata. Nessun limite alla creatività, nessuna regola.

Le 21 opere realizzate saranno esposte a Trieste, in riva al mare, in 5 container, prima luoghi destinati al trasporto di merci e cibi, ora contenitori d’arte.


Perché per noi il cibo più sano è la libertà di creare.


Perché vi chiediamo una mano

Mesi di ricerca, lavoro, preparazione, contatti, creazione di legami e rapporti, definizioni e ridefinizioni, riunioni infinite, notti in bianco, conti sempre in rosso, qualche mojito in compagnia per stemperare i momenti difficili. Eppure i soldi non bastano.

I costi per i noleggi, l'uso del suolo pubblico, le assicurazioni, la stampa di alto livello, gli allestimenti, sono sempre alti. Quest'anno più degli altri anni.

Siamo ormai vicini alla mostra e, in un modo o nell'altro, la vogliamo assolutamente realizzare. Senza rinunciare mai alla qualità, senza compromessi.

Ecco il perché di questa "campagna lampo": la nostra è una richiesta a tutti quelli che, come noi, non vogliono mai rinunciare, anche quando i numeri non vogliono proprio tornare.

Come puoi aiutarci senza donare

Se non puoi contribuire donado, condividici! In questo modo la nostra campagna potrà raggingere un maggior numero di persone. Grazie!

story:
The Black Rock Blind Tiger is a novel speakeasy conceived around the idea of participation and play.  To gain access, you must solve the exterior puzzles and discover the password that allows entry.  Not in the mood for mysteries?  No worries, friend—the Black Rock Blind Tiger offers something for everyone, whether it’s a moment’s respite on the widow’s walk, or a secret gift found while exploring. 

Our team of artists and builders are fixing up and rebuilding parts of the structures.  We are making sure every little detail is taken care of in the interactive 1920s speakeasy for all Burning Man participants to experience and enjoy.  We’ll have interactive gifts, scintillating conversation, and excellent jazz music to keep you dancing the night away.  But the Black Rock Blind Tiger is more than just a speakeasy.  Join us and delight in the curious art, the unusual objects, and the many surprises that await you inside of the Black Rock Blind Tiger. 

 

The Inspiration

The Black Rock Blind Tiger is inspired by prohibition-era speakeasies, or secret drinking establishments that often required a password to gain entry.  Occasionally thirsty people skirted prohibition laws by acquiring “prescriptions” for “medicinal” drinks that were otherwise unlawful.  Sometimes these drinks were served through a secret drawer so that the identity of the server was never revealed. The name “Blind Tiger” itself is code for an illegal drinking establishment where the seller's identity was concealed.

 

The Team

The Black Rock Blind Tiger is based out of Austin, Texas and led by veteran Burning Man and Burning Flipside attendee Tiffaney Benson.  The team includes a 20+ person crew of artists, mixologists, builders, designers, and do’ers.  For more about our team, see our Team Bios page:  http://www.blackrockblindtiger.com/artist-and-t...

 

Funding

We’re raising funds to bring The Black Rock Blind Tiger back to the playa for Burning Man 2017.  To date we have raised $3,000 through local fundraisers, but we have $4,000 remaining to meet our goal.  Our major expenses include building supplies, transportation, supplies for the speakeasy, gadgets and insurance.  

The Black Rock Blind Tiger is a volunteer-led project supported entirely by our team members, fundraiser attendees, and Indiegogo campaign backers.  Your support of our campaign allows us to bring back our dream of a community speakeasy to the playa in 2017.  

 

Perks

Stickers:

For a $15 donation, get a cool Blind Tiger sticker to stick on all your things and a big thanks from us.

 

Bandanas:

For a $25 donation, get a handy cotton tiger stripe bandana with our logo to wipe away all that playa dust.  

 

Blind Tiger Brothel Poster:

For a $30 donation, get a super fun pin-up style poster from the Blind Tiger Brothel sign.

 

Aluminum Logo Water Bottle or Stainless Steel Logo Flask:

For a $40 donation, get your choice of an aluminum logo water bottle with a screw top and a carabiner, OR a 6 oz. stainless steel flask with a leather wrap and our logo on it! 

 

T-shirts:

For a $50 donation, get a t-shirt with our crew logo screen-printed on the front and the Burning Man closed prohibition sign on the back.  T-shirts are dark grey, crew neck, 50/50 ring spun combed cotton and polyester for softness and durability.  Available in either men's or women's sizes XS-3X. 

Women's t-shirt style:

Men's t-shirt style:

 

Hoodies:

For a $75 donation, Get your own personalized clue with your name on The Speakeasy on the play and stay warm and get a hoodie with our crew logo screen-printed on the front and the Burning Man prohibition closed sign on the back.  Hoodies are dark grey and pull-over style in 50/50 cotton and poly fleece.  Sizes XS-3X. 

 

 Glasses:

For a $100 donation, get 4 swanky glasses with our logo etched on them.  Glasses will have a copper, silver or gold dipped honeycomb design (handwash only). 

 

Decanter + bar glasses:

For a $200 donation, get both a decanter and a set of glasses with our logo etched onto them.  Decanter and glasses will have a copper, silver or gold dipped honeycomb design (handwash only).

 

 

Speakeasy Sunset Sail on Lake Travis:

For $600 donation, enjoy a beautiful sunset sail on lake travis with 3 of your friends.  You will be sipping on cocktails with the wind blowing in your hair watching the sun melt into the horizon.  Delicious Hors d'oeuvres will be served with the fine cocktails.

 

Other Ways to Help

If you want to make a non-monetary donation, contact the Blind Tiger team at blackrockblindtiger@gmail.com.  We are in need of vintage furniture and knick-knacks, building supplies, gas and grocery gift cards, alcohol, and many other things!

 

Learn More

http://www.blackrockblindtiger.com/

https://www.facebook.com/blackrockblindtiger/

 

Thanks:

Thank you Dust To Ashes for the Amazing Bathtub Brothel photo.  See more amazing photos at www.dusttoashes.com.
story_txt: The Black Rock Blind Tiger is a novel speakeasy conceived around the idea of participation and play.  To gain access, you must solve the exterior puzzles and discover the password that allows entry.  Not in the mood for mysteries?  No worries, friend—the Black Rock Blind Tiger offers something for everyone, whether it’s a moment’s respite on the widow’s walk, or a secret gift found while exploring. Our team of artists and builders are fixing up and rebuilding parts of the structures.  We are making sure every little detail is taken care of in the interactive 1920s speakeasy for all Burning Man participants to experience and enjoy.  We’ll have interactive gifts, scintillating conversation, and excellent jazz music to keep you dancing the night away.  But the Black Rock Blind Tiger is more than just a speakeasy.  Join us and delight in the curious art, the unusual objects, and the many surprises that await you inside of the Black Rock Blind Tiger.  The InspirationThe Black Rock Blind Tiger is inspired by prohibition-era speakeasies, or secret drinking establishments that often required a password to gain entry.  Occasionally thirsty people skirted prohibition laws by acquiring “prescriptions” for “medicinal” drinks that were otherwise unlawful.  Sometimes these drinks were served through a secret drawer so that the identity of the server was never revealed. The name “Blind Tiger” itself is code for an illegal drinking establishment where the seller's identity was concealed. The TeamThe Black Rock Blind Tiger is based out of Austin, Texas and led by veteran Burning Man and Burning Flipside attendee Tiffaney Benson.  The team includes a 20+ person crew of artists, mixologists, builders, designers, and do’ers.  For more about our team, see our Team Bios page:  http://www.blackrockblindtiger.com/artist-and-t... FundingWe’re raising funds to bring The Black Rock Blind Tiger back to the playa for Burning Man 2017.  To date we have raised $3,000 through local fundraisers, but we have $4,000 remaining to meet our goal.  Our major expenses include building supplies, transportation, supplies for the speakeasy, gadgets and insurance.  The Black Rock Blind Tiger is a volunteer-led project supported entirely by our team members, fundraiser attendees, and Indiegogo campaign backers.  Your support of our campaign allows us to bring back our dream of a community speakeasy to the playa in 2017.   PerksStickers:For a $15 donation, get a cool Blind Tiger sticker to stick on all your things and a big thanks from us. Bandanas:For a $25 donation, get a handy cotton tiger stripe bandana with our logo to wipe away all that playa dust.   Blind Tiger Brothel Poster:For a $30 donation, get a super fun pin-up style poster from the Blind Tiger Brothel sign. Aluminum Logo Water Bottle or Stainless Steel Logo Flask:For a $40 donation, get your choice of an aluminum logo water bottle with a screw top and a carabiner, OR a 6 oz. stainless steel flask with a leather wrap and our logo on it!  T-shirts:For a $50 donation, get a t-shirt with our crew logo screen-printed on the front and the Burning Man closed prohibition sign on the back.  T-shirts are dark grey, crew neck, 50/50 ring spun combed cotton and polyester for softness and durability.  Available in either men's or women's sizes XS-3X. Women's t-shirt style:Men's t-shirt style: Hoodies:For a $75 donation, Get your own personalized clue with your name on The Speakeasy on the play and stay warm and get a hoodie with our crew logo screen-printed on the front and the Burning Man prohibition closed sign on the back.  Hoodies are dark grey and pull-over style in 50/50 cotton and poly fleece.  Sizes XS-3X.   Glasses:For a $100 donation, get 4 swanky glasses with our logo etched on them.  Glasses will have a copper, silver or gold dipped honeycomb design (handwash only).  Decanter + bar glasses:For a $200 donation, get both a decanter and a set of glasses with our logo etched onto them.  Decanter and glasses will have a copper, silver or gold dipped honeycomb design (handwash only).  Speakeasy Sunset Sail on Lake Travis:For $600 donation, enjoy a beautiful sunset sail on lake travis with 3 of your friends.  You will be sipping on cocktails with the wind blowing in your hair watching the sun melt into the horizon.  Delicious Hors d'oeuvres will be served with the fine cocktails. Other Ways to HelpIf you want to make a non-monetary donation, contact the Blind Tiger team at blackrockblindtiger@gmail.com.  We are in need of vintage furniture and knick-knacks, building supplies, gas and grocery gift cards, alcohol, and many other things! Learn Morehttp://www.blackrockblindtiger.com/https://www.facebook.com/blackrockblindtiger/ Thanks:Thank you Dust To Ashes for the Amazing Bathtub Brothel photo.  See more amazing photos at www.dusttoashes.com.

story:
My name is Mary Platz Hughes
I am an artist from Kent Ohio.  I received my BFA at Kent State University.  I am married to the wonderful Mark Hughes.
This book was inspired by my friend Scott Pickering. 
I wrote this book to support anyone who feels insecure because they feel different.
It is not easy sometimes being an artist. I am sure other people feel the same way.  
It is a cute story and a labor of love. Please help me publish Toad Story so I can share my story.
The money will go toward  the publishing costs of my book.  It will be a soft cover book.  The size is 5.5 x 8.5 inches.
Everyone who contributes will get a magnet. Every one of the perks is something i made.  The $10 perk is a blank card from a series of card designs inspired by my wonderful sister in law Vicki.
The $20 perk is a small print i made.  It is not in the book.  It is only for this fundraiser.  
the $50 perk  is a t-shirt of the Toad Story cover design.
If you contribute $100 or more you will get one of each of all of these items.

Please help me get the word out and support your local artists.  Thank you <3

UPDATE: I WILL GIVE DONATIONS OF 50 DOLLARS AND  HIGHER  A COPY OF TOAD STORY!

story:
Who am I?

I am a printmaker asking for your support to help me build a community print shop in Newark, NJ for people who are interested in printmaking and need a space to practice it.

When I first started printing, it was the collaborative setting in my University's print studio that got me hooked. Once I set up a small printing press in my studio, I immediately wanted to share it with other artists in my community, and the Newark Print Shop was born. I hosted weekly open studio PRINT CLUBS with an open door policy, and it quickly sparked a rebirth of printmaking in Newark. We existed for less than a year in my studio until a fire in our building forced us out. Now we are looking to relocate and make the Newark Print Shop bigger and better!

What I want to do is develop a space that if you have an interest in the fine art of printmaking, you can come and experience it and be a part of a community of other printmakers.

We all have dreams and this is about keeping the dream of the NEWARK PRINT SHOP alive.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to get the Newark Print Shop back off the ground we need new space and funds to develop it. Your donation will help cover the initial costs of acquiring and building out new space. These costs include plumbing, track lighting installation, contractor fees, and construction of workstations.

Although we have most of our equipment in storage, we still need a few additional things to ensure we are offering the best to our fellow printmakers.
Your donation helps cover the costs to purchase this equipment.

Your contribution also strengthens and develops the arts and culture scene in Newark, and creates compelling evidence of community support of Newark Print Shop to others across our community. We are trying to reach the goal of $5,000 in 1 month. Every little bit helps!

In exchange for your donation, we are excited to offer you unique perks. You can receive: unique artist prints, handprinted tote bags, tshirts, hats and more all printed at the Newark Print Shop. In addition we would love to offer you personal tours of our beloved city and the galleries and spaces that make up the art community here.

Our Print Equipment:

What We Have:

  • 24" Conrad Etching Press
  • Spring Loaded Drying Rack
  • Homemade Exposure Unit for Photographic Processes
  • Table-top Kelsey Letterpress
  • Hollander Beater for Papermaking
  • Slop Sink
  • Washout Booth for Screenprinting
  • Ferric Chloride Bath for Copper Etching
  • Flat Files
  • Squeegees, Brayers, Rollers

What We Still Need:

  • Vacuum Sealed Exposure Unit for Screenprinting
  • Hydraulic Press for Drying Handmade Paper
  • Epson Printer for Making Film Positives for Screenprinting
  • Computer for Media Station

The Impact:

The new location would afford us the much-needed space we require in order to grow some of our programs, including a key-holder membership program, adult education through classes and workshops, exhibition programming, and a 4-month residency program. Newark Print Shop seeks to be a dynamic and active space serving the greater Newark Arts Community!

Who We Will Help!

Students:


(Local high school students learning bookbinding in our inaugural youth outreach program, ArtBound)

Artists interested in learning about printmaking:


(Participants of Colleen Gutwein's Cyanotype Workshop)

Printmakers:



(Happy printers during open studio PRINT CLUBS)

We would love your help!

  • Follow Newark Print Shop on Facebook
  • Share this campain! Tweet it! Like it! Blog it!
  • Send this campain out to your network of art + culture enthusiasts
  • Consider making a donation today :)
  • Follow your dreams and work hard to make it happen!

Use the power of the people to make good things happen for your community.

More info about Newark Print Shop:

NEWARKPRINTSHOP.ORG
FACEBOOK
FLICKR
INSTAGRAM
TUMBLR
SHAMEFUL DESIGNS
GLOCALLY NEWARK

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

story:
GOOD FOLKS.

Jesse and Larry here. 

It's Fall, 2014, and we're still kicking and screaming and shifting and moving here in the Bay Area. There's so much good and there's so much bad and WE NEED YOUR HELP.

 Here's the work:

In our ongoing quest to haul the arts out from its often-strangled position in our economy, we're honing in on the task of changing the actual dominant systems of value around art. These dominant systems ensure that artists remain in constant servitude to wealth and for-profit projects, that we are casually reaped for our creations and cultural contributions, and that we are made to constantly assess our worth in terms of competitive and anti-art deliverables that place us in a fictitious, endless funding-seeking infrastructure that only wants to keep us utterly marginalized. We're pissed, we're buzzing, we're tired, but we're not dead yet, so...

One strategy that we're leaning into heavily right now is the act of elevating PRACTICE:

So…how do we insist on the value of our practices, which are arguably the bones, muscles and blood of our lives as artists; the actions that last long before and after our "pieces" are done, our funding is dry, and our careers have been made socio-economically impossible? Can we redefine what art operates as, by veering our critical attention away from the art object or "piece", and instead inviting audiences into our work and creating experiences and sensations that are INCLUSIVE of our actual practices of being artists? Shouldn't we be dismantling the notion that artists are people who produce things, inside of capitalism, for other people to experience or have, and instead be expanding the reality that artists are actually people whose personal and creative practices are rigorous locations for imagining change? Shouldn't  creative practice be an expanded concept that more people can identify themselves in? Let's rally around practice, look at it closely, let it compose our reality, honor it obsessively, and allow it to give us connectivity, catharsis, and criticality.

For the week of November 10th-16th, we are programming ALL THE PRACTICE, an entire week of action at Z Space in San Francisco, all dedicated to making art, conversations, and happenings that will elevate PRACTICE. We are inviting YOU and an army of rigorous artists practicing in and around forms of dance and performance to gather, practice, watch each other practice, learn each other's practices, practice seeing the practice in places where we might not usually look for it, talk about new ideas for funding/resources/support, listen to our elders, and take stock of what it is to lead of life of practice. Also, this is a week to think and feel critically about what a "practice" really is, and how when we have one, we really do have SO MUCH. We are the art, people..and lord knows, we must not allow ourselves to be bought and sold so easily. 


Here's the schedule!

-Tuesday Nov. 11th, 7:30pm: Dance Discourse Project #20: ALL THE PRACTICE with guest panelists: Margy Jenkins, Brontez Purnell, Nina Haft, Dia Dear, and Sara Shelton Mann

-Wednesday Nov. 12th, 8pm: 100 REASONS TO LIVE:  a night of many many many experiential offerings from each of us to each of you. 

-Thursday Nov. 13th, times TBA: OPEN SPACE for practice sharing and conversation

-Friday Nov. 14th, 8pm:  THE PRACTICE SHOW: parallel experiments and studies, with Amara Tabor-Smith, Maria Francesca Scaroni, Jassem Hindi, Tove Sahlin, Monique Jenkinson, Annie Danger, Tossie Long, Marina Fukishima, Daiane Lopes Da Silva, Larry Arrington, Allie Hankins, Keyon Gaskin, Brontez Purnell, and Abby Crain

-Saturday Nov. 15th, 8pm: 2 new works/practices, "WE" by Larry Arrington, and "just in the yard"  by Jesse Hewit

-Sunday Nov. 16th, 8pm: 2 new works/practices, "WE" by Larry Arrington, and "just in the yard" by Jesse Hewit

We need $4,000 to pay the league of incredible artists of this week!

The break down is this:

  • We have roughly 25 guest artists working in various capacities throughout the week, and we need to be able to give them each honorariums for their contributions.
  • We are enthusiastically working in tandem with Z Space to present this week of programming, and we are working from a small amount of grant money to cover basic costs, but we still need to PAY OURSELVES for the many months of practice, organizing, administering, and art-making that is going into this week.
  • AND…we MUST meet our entire goal of $4,000 or we get NONE! whoa! Jesse has NEVER done a crowd-funding campaign before and Larry's only done one, so we're banking on our novice status and "alternative" charms.

    ALSO: we know that money is SUPER WEIRD...

    …and some people just can't contribute. This economy is a truly overwhelming maze of a thing, and we know how lost people can feel inside of it. If you can't help out with a little money, please know that we really feel you and like you, and we'll still throw you twenty bucks when you need it. WE FIGHT THE SCARCITY BY PRACTICING ABUNDANCE. Magic is real, people. Let's do this.

-Sunday Nov. 16th, 8pm: 2 new works/practices, "WE" by Larry Arrington, and "just in the yard" by Jesse Hewit   We need $4,000 to pay the league of incredible artists of this week! The break down is this: 
We have roughly 25 guest artists working in various capacities throughout the week, and we need to be able to give them each honorariums for their contributions. We are enthusiastically working in tandem with Z Space to present this week of programming, and we are working from a small amount of grant money to cover basic costs, but we still need to PAY OURSELVES for the many months of practice, organizing, administering, and art-making that is going into this week. AND…we MUST meet our entire goal of $4,000 or we get NONE! whoa! Jesse has NEVER done a crowd-funding campaign before and Larry's only done one, so we're banking on our novice status and "alternative" charms.

  ALSO: we know that money is SUPER WEIRD... …and some people just can't contribute. This economy is a truly overwhelming maze of a thing, and we know how lost people can feel inside of it. If you can't help out with a little money, please know that we really feel you and like you, and we'll still throw you twenty bucks when you need it. WE FIGHT THE SCARCITY BY PRACTICING ABUNDANCE. Magic is real, people. Let's do this.

story:
The Big Picture

What is BUSNEST?

BUSNEST is a performance art piece and routed bus tour that uses workshops and performances to address race politics and cultural appropriation in music and dance, specifically of the African diaspora in the United States. We believe there is a lack of awareness of how sampling music and dance from other cultures can be appropriative. As a result of this lack of awareness, it is visible from our work in music and dance productions as well as in the academic study of these concepts, that there is a different understanding of the ethics of creative exchange across professions, socio economic and racial communities.

What does this "different understanding!" mean?

It means that artists like Iggy Azalea can pick and choose parts of black culture that are advantageous and profitable to her career while not having to experience the everyday oppression of black communities. It means that the aesthetic history of twerking rooted in the canonical quality of groundedness found in West African dance is lost to the mockery of and commodification by Miley Cyrus.

These questions raise concerns of how sampling other cultural aesthetics can be socio-economically, ethically and culturally damaging to the sampled.

OUR STORY

Frances and Sophia first met on a bus at Hampshire College. What began as a shared commute developed into a whole hearted investment into what is now BUSNEST, Frances and Sophia's senior thesis project. Frances Caperchi born and bred in Rome, Italy, majors in ethnomusicology and cultural studies and is one of the lead organizers of on campus music shows and festivals. Sophia Philip, native New Yorker, studies West African dance and anthropology and has organized various conferences from TEDx. On the original bus they found a shared interest in delving deeper into what it meant to be white European and American women passionate about music and dance from non-Western cultures. First, they thought a concert was the answer, but after talking to professors and peers they realized that there was more to be learned and more to be explored. Three years later, after hundreds of meetings, organizing concerts, discussions and workshops, BUSNEST came to be.

Through socially engaged art, BUSNEST is an experimental classroom and community space to discuss how each of us establish who we are through dance and music, understand how we participate in producing culture through the arts and how our roles, whether as intellectuals or musicians, influence the way we view, listen to or create dance and music.


What We Need & What You Get

Total Budget: $6,633  (includes +10%)

Bus Rental: $380

Lighting: $300

Performer Fees: $4000

Food: $600

Miscellaneous Materials: $550

Advertisement: $200


Perks Include...

Italian cooking lessons with Frances

Personalised oil paintings by Sophia

Digital documentation of the event

BUSNEST T-Shirts

And much more...


The Impact

The audience of BUSNEST are academics, musicians, dancers and the general public.  The arts can be a platform for discussing politics and civic engagement. Often those discussions are exclusive or not taken seriously. Our mission is to acknowledge that we are all culture makers and that each of us has a story and role that shapes the music and dance industry. We hope that BUSNEST can offer a framework or “social sculpture” to make it easier to have conversations about social concerns and cultivate action with more communities through the arts.


Other Ways You Can Help

Get us in touch with sponsors or food vendors who are willing to lend a hand. And of course: spread the word!

story:
I will be applying to the Jewellery Art and Design program at Vancouver Community College this fall. For my project, I have decided to take my passion for crystals, stones and jewellery design, and to create a portfolio of my own designs. To do so, I need the funding to be able to purchase the necessary materials. Once I have the materials, I can create all of the pieces that I design to further add to my portfolio.
I joined a gem and mineral club last year which allowed me the opportunity to take an introduction to metalsmithing and lapidary, and have been in love with it ever since I started. Depicted above is some of my previous work from what I have created since joining the club. I hope to create further designs using the same techniques and skills that I have learned by making these pieces. I simply need somewhere to start. 


Please help make my dream a reality!

Thank you kindly,

Agatha F

story:
| русская версия ниже |


Introduction

I am a performance artist and musician based in London.
My current work draws inspiration from rituals, especially those from ancient cultures, as a way to bring the public back into connection with themselves and their roots. In our modern city life we often move at such a fast pace we lose touch with ourselves and with each other. My art works attempt to slow the public down and bring about a deeply meditative experience in which they can connect more deeply to themselves and others. Through my collaboration with Marina Abramovic in 2014 I also saw how important this direction is in art and how strongly it affects the public.

 In July 2015 I was invited for a month-long residency at London's prestigious Barbican Centre. There I presented two new works, 'Ancestors' based on the ancient rituals and meditative music of my Lithuanian roots with Lithuanian folk singers 'Trys Keturiose'.

Now I am seeking to go even deeper into this type of research, this time working with Buryat shamans in Lake Baikal, Russia.

Short summary

Siberian shamanism is one of the oldest traditions in the world, deeply connected to nature and to its roots and ancestors. From my research on these rich traditions and the incredible natural beauty of Lake Baikal and sacred places in Buryatia (mountains, volcanoes, rivers), I will create a new series of performances as well as a video installation together with artist Konstantin Guz which will show in a two-week solo exhibition at Fabrika Centre for Creative Industries in Moscow, October 2016.               

Konstantin Guz is a visual artist and photographer based in Amsterdam. His work crosses interdisciplinary boundaries and explores the medium of photography and moving image in all its depths and facets.

We also have plans to bring this exhibition on tour to the UK, USA, Netherlands, and other European countries.

Motivation

I want to learn from Shamans about the traditions of the Buryat people and their connection with ancestors and traditions which go back thousands of years.

This project is extremely valuable to my artistic development, and I believe that through my experiences in Buryatia and work with shamans I will be even better able to approach my audiences and transform both myself and the public's emotional state through performance. 

Inspiration

Shamanism is an ancient tradition, Siberian shamanism being one of the oldest religions, which involves a person (shaman) entering into a trance-like state through music, dance, and song, during which he or she can communicate with the spirits of dead ancestors and nature, in order to bring harmony and balance to our lives on earth.  What interests me so much is their connection and respect for their ancestral traditions, as well as nature. In Buryatia, there are many fascinating natural sites sacred to shamanism, which we will visit and will be an integral part of our video work. One, for example is the island of Olkhon, in Lake Baikal, which has many special places, for example the Shaman's Rock: 

'One of the most mysterious of the Baikal sites. It is on Cape Burkhan, earlier called the "Stone Temple." It is comprised of white marble, granite and quartz. The first explorers to reach Lake Baikal – including the Russian scientist Vladimir Obruchev – noted that Baikal Buryats traditionally feared this site. Only shamans had the right to approach this forbidden place. If it couldn't be avoided, horses' hoofs were wrapped in felt and leather so they did not disturb the lord of Baikal.

Buryats believed that Azhin (Buryat for deity), the lord of Lake Baikal, lived in the cave at Shaman Rock. According to the testimony of villagers who lived at Khunzhir, located near Cape Burkhan, the cave was visited by shamans that settled in ancient Siberia. Pagan priests still perform rituals in the cave associated with cleansing ancestral karma and removing curses.'-A Traveller's guide to Siberia 



What We Need

I have generously received some funding from the EU Cultural Foundation to cover my own flight costs to Siberia, but in order to realize this project I need your support.

  • In addition to myself, I have invited visual artist, Konstantin Guz, to film and photograph during our travels in Buryatia. I will need funds to pay :
- artist fee to Konstantin;
- his travel expenses and flights (from his city of origin to Buryatia)
- hotels and accommodation for both of us while traveling and food.
You find more about him and his work here:
    http://konstantinguz.com

  • During our travels in Buryatia and Baikal we will need to hire an experienced guide in order to travel safely and explore the remote mountains and islands of Lake Baikal. 
  • I will also need support to cover my internal travel costs (accommodation and land-transport) in Buryatia.
  • Cost of renting the equipment for filming and editing films.

Perks: Depending on donation 

  • Donators will be listed as exhibition sponsors at Fabrika CCI, as well as all future exhibitions related with this funding project. 
  • You will also be gifted with high-quality photographs, field recordings, posters, and film of our travels in spectacularly beautiful mountains and forests of Buryatia, Lake Baikal and its islands, as well as other places considered sacred to Buryat shamanism. 
  • Highest giving donors will be gifted with photographs as well as limited-edition footage from the video made in Buryatia, and video artworks for private home screening.


The Impact

I strongly believe that in the 21st Century we are losing our roots - we are losing the rituals of our ancestors which keep us grounded and able to connect with the rhythms of life. We begin to forget that we ourselves, as pure human beings, have a deep strength and power that no technology can ever give. Through returning to older cultures and traditions, I create contemporary art works that seek to bring the public back into balance and harmony with themselves, contemplating their origins as well as bringing them to feel fully in the present moment. 

During this project "Lake of Sacred Souls: Journey to Baikal" I will keep an online journal via Facebook page and Instagram updating with news, photos of the journey and sharing fascinating facts about that region.

Where the project will be shown?

The premier of the project, performance and video installation, will be held at two-week solo exhibition at Fabrika CCI Gallery in Moscow, October 2016. 

After that event we also have plans to bring this exhibition on tour to the UK, USA, Netherlands, and other European countries.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campaign in your social media, Facebook, Instagram, blogs and tell your friends who might be interested to support.
  • Use Indiegogo share tools


Thank you so much for your interest and I am so grateful for any support you can give!


____________________________________________________________________________


Введение

­­­

Меня зовут Абраам Броди.

Я-перформер и музыкант, живущий и работающий в Лондоне. Работая над текущим проектом, я черпаю вдохновение из ритуалов, тех что берут свое начало в древних культурах.  Наша современная городская жизнь бежит так быстро, что мы теряем связь и с самим собой, и с друг другом.  В основе моих арт работ лежит попытка «замедления» публики, давая им возможность испытать глубокий медитативный опыт, который даст им возможность соединиться с собой и другими. Благодаря моему сотрудничеству с Мариной Абрамович в 2014 году я увидел как важно это направление в искусстве и насколько сильно это влияет на публику. 

В июле 2015 года я был приглашен на месячную резиденцию в престижном Barbican Centre в Лондоне. Там я представил две новые работы «Предки», основанную на древних ритуалах и медитативной музыки моих литовских корней.  Сейчас я стремлюсь глубже исследовать эту тему, на этот раз взаимодействуя с шаманами Бурятии на берегах озера Байкал. 

Краткое содержание

Сибирский шаманизм-одна из старейших в мире традиций, тесно связанная с природой и почитающая свои корни и предков.  Основываясь на своем исследовании богатых традиций, невероятной природной красоте озера Байкал и священных мест Бурятии, я создам новую серию перформансов, а также видео инсталляцию совместно с современным визуальным художником Константином Гузь, которые будут представлены на 2-х недельной соло выставке в Центре Творческих Индустрий ФАБРИКА, Москва, осенью 2016 года.
У нас также есть планы показа этой выставки в Великобритании, США, Голландии и других европейских странах.

Мотивация

Я хочу получить знания шаманов о многовековых традициях народа Бурятии и связях с их предками. Этот проект является чрезвычайно ценным для моего творческого развития, и я считаю, что через мой опыт в Бурятии и работе с шаманами я буду еще лучше взаимодействовать с моей аудиторией и трансформировать себя и эмоциональное состояние публики через перформанс.

Вдохновление

Шаманизм-это древняя традиция, а Сибирский шаманизм является одной из самых старых религий. Шаман- человек, входящий в состояние транса через музыку и танец, в течение которого он способен общаться с духами предков и природой. Что меня действительно интересует, так это то уважение, которое они уделяют этим традициям. В Бурятии большое количество интересных природных образований, являющихся священными местами шаманов, которые я планирую посетить. Одно из них, гора Шаманка, находится на острове Ольхон:

"Одно из самых загадочных мест на Байкале. Оно находится на мысе Бурхан, ранее называемый "Каменный храм." Состоит из белого мрамора, гранита и кварца. Первые исследователи, добравшиеся до озера Байкал - в том числе российский ученый Владимир Обручев - отметили, что буряты согласно традиции боялись этого места. Только шаманы имели право подойти к этому запрещенному месту. Если этой дороги не удавалось избежать, копыта лошадей заворачивали в войлок и кожу, дабы не потревожить владыку Байкала.

Буряты считали, что дух, владыка озера Байкал, жил в пещере горы Шаманка. По свидетельству жителей села, которые жили в поселке Хунжир, расположенного недалеко от мыса Бурхан, эту пещеру посещали шаманы, которые обосновались в древней Сибири. Языческие жрецы по-прежнему выполняют в пещере ритуалы, связанные с очищением родовой кармы и удаления проклятий.

Что нам нужно и что получаете вы

Я уже получил грант от Фонда культуры ЕС для покрытия моих транспортных расходов и перелета до Иркутска, но для того, чтобы полностью реализовать этот проект, я нуждаюсь в вашей поддержке.

• Дополнительно в проект я пригласил визуального художника Константина Гузь для документации нашей поездки по Бурятии и в последствии создания видео инсталяции.

Денежные средства пойдут на:

- артистический гонорар Константину Гузь;

- оплату путешествия, авиа перелета художника до Бурятии;

- оплатау проживание и питания художника.

Информация о творчестве - http://konstantinguz.com

• Для нашего перемещения по Бурятии и побережью озера Байкал нам необходим опытный гид-проводник для безопасного путешествия в отдаленные горные участки и на острова Байкала.

• Мне также необходимо оплатить мои внутренние транспортные расходы (проживание и наземный транспорт) в Бурятии.

• Для определенных целей нам будет необходима аренда фото/видео оборудования

Поощрительные подарки (в зависимости от суммы пожертвования)

-  Донаторы будут упомянуты в качестве спонсоров выставки в Центре Творческих Индустрий ФАБРИКА, Москва, а также в последующих выставках с участием данного проекта.

-  Мы подарим вам хорошего разрешения и высокого качества фотографии артиста во время его путешествия по невероятно красивым горам и лесам Бурятии, озеру Байкал с его островами, а также по священным местам шаманов.

-  Для тех, кто пожертвует большую сумму, получит в подарок хорошего разрешения и высокого качества фотографии плюс отдельные видео зарисовки и готовую арт работу для домашней видео коллекции.

Влияние проекта

Я твердо убежден, что в 21 веке мы теряем наши корни, мы теряем обряды наших предков, которые приземляют нас и дают возможность соединиться с ритмом жизни. Мы начинаем забывать, что мы сами, как чистые человеческие существа, имеем ту глубокую силу и мощь, что ни одна технология никогда не сможет дать. Через возвращение к старым культурам и традициям, я создаю современные произведения искусства, которые стремятся привести публику в равновесие и к гармонии с самими собой, созерцая свое происхождение и ощущая полноту чувств в настоящий момент.

Во время моего путешествия я буду держать вас в курсе происходящего, делясь новостями, впечатлениями и фотографиями через FB страницу проекта, Instagram и свой сайт.

Где будет показан проект

Премьера проекта, перформанс и видео инсталяция, состоится в рамках 2х-недельной соло выставки в Центре Творческих Индустрий ФАБРИКА, Москва, осенью 2016 года.
У нас также есть планы показа этой выставки в Великобритании, США, Голландии и других европейских странах.

Как еще можно помочь

Пожалуйста, поделитесь ссылкой на проект в ваших социальных сетях: Фэйсбук, Вконтакте, Инстаграм, личных блогах и расскажите друзьям!

Также можете воспользоваться инструментами Indiegogo


Большое вам спасибо за ваш интерес, и я очень благодарен за любую поддержку, которую вы можете оказать!
